review_title: Great investment of time and effort if you can get in a great lab or program
job_title: Research Associate in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
* Opportunity to work with smaller pool of great (internationally well known) Professors.
* If you're talented and you know it, you will stand out and get rewarded (papers, referrals and etc).
* This place filters out competitive people, so you won't have to work with someone who will stomp you down needlessly or take your work.
* People will want to see you (as a person) succeed. Again, smaller pool means better opportunity to stick out.
* Money is available.
* The opportunity and reward is there, it all depends on what you make of it, in my opinion and experience.
* Depending on where you are with your career, Rutgers will provide opportunities but will not necessarily hold your hand.
* RU is 30 mi away from NYC and about 75 mi from Phila which means you can take a day trip to another university to attend a seminar/conference/class in case Rutgers isn't hosting that particular speaker (always a good option).
* New Brunswick is surrounded by safe and beautiful suburbs with fantastic public school systems.
* Healthy diversity on campus.
cons:
* Just as the stand-out PIs flock together, complacency and herd mentality with found with older PIs. Stay away from these labs and you will do fine.
* Independence but isolation felt when working in newer subject areas.
* Parking, parking rules and parking tickets (arrghhh).
* Traffic to campus at peak times can be frustrating so plan accordingly.

job_title: Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Plenty of hours to go around. 
Easy work.  
Glorified Google searcher. 
Fairly decent wage for a college student.
cons:
This job is basically answering phones all day to help people who are too stupid to understand how to search google. 

Essentially you go and sit in a call center for the entirety of your shift and no matter what you happen to be doing at that moment, eating lunch, answering an email, giving CPR as soon as the phone rings it becomes your one and only priorty. 

There are at least 15-20 full-time managers  who all do pretty much nothing but joke around with each other all day with their thumbs up their butts while the part time slaves (i mean students) do all the work and yell at you to get back on the phones if you take longer than a 2 minute break. 

You are not allowed to reach 40 hours a week so they dont have to pay you any benifits. 

Promotions are given to students entirely on how much butt you kiss and how much the supervisors like you. Not on merit at all. 

Work is mindless, repetitive and soul-numbing.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
I was a teaching assistant for the physics department as a grad student, so I was very happy that for 20 hours of work a week I had tuition paid for and a livable stipend.  The students were generally decent, if not always interested, and my supervising professor was excellent.  I heard from co-workers that this was not the case with all of the professors you could possibly teach for though.  As I think is typical of teaching, a lot of the time I felt as though my efforts were not appreciated by my students, but I realize that does not have to do with Rutgers as a school or employer.

We also had fairly useful new teaching assistants training sessions throughout the semester to give us a crash course in teaching methods and how to deal with classroom management.
cons: Some professors (though not mine) give very little guidance as to how they expect you to teach the class, students do not always want to be there (which means you often feel a though your teaching is doing no good), and the grading is always a chore.

review_title: A struggling higher education institution with significant need for reform.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Formerly there were very good benefits associated with employment. Tuition remission for children helps off set the cost of attending the university. Very broad and diverse work environment
cons: There is a significant disconnect between those working with the students and those in the upper administration.  Typically the upper administration follow political guided back scratching over putting the students first. Office buildings are worn and show significant aging. My former building the wall paper was peeling off and anytime one bumped up against a wall they would come away covered in powder.  Additionally do to misalignment of budgets many employees are being stuck with decreasing benefits while salaries of the upper administration continue to rise.  There are constant salary freezes and minimal compensation when contract issues are resolved.

review_title: Good way to make connections, but a disorganized workplace
job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Good way for students to get to know teachers better outside the classroom. This really helps if you need a recommendation for graduate school or a job.

Good insight into the workings of higher education for those who are interested in pursuing a career in university teaching/administration.
cons:
I was by far the most organized person there. A lot of my work involved wading through the layers of bureaucracy just to get simple things done, like copies of class materials.

I think that people's experience depends on the professor they are working for. In my case the prof. was a great guy and easy to work for, but in interacting with the other people in administration I found that there is a frustrating amount waste. While there are some very helpful and nice people working at Rutgers, I thought that far too many were lazy, and they often acted like they were doing me a favor by simply doing their jobs.

review_title: Great Benefits but Some Departments Have Management Problems
job_title: Programmer Analyst in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
- Great Benefits (PTO, Insurance, Retirement, Tuition Reimbursement)
- Many areas to work into (Many positions internally within the University)
- In a position to learn a lot of new things, for better or for worse
- Unionized
cons: Management.  Some departments, some supervisors can cause a department to underperform.  One common method on how they operate is when they would dilberatly make an employee feel undervalued by putting them in a position of guilt.  Since were unionized, it isn't easy to lose a position but they will greatly lower your morale by constantyl berating your performance and threatening further displcinary action between HR.  This puts employees in a position where they would end up working harder but it wouldn't be enough to please their superiors.

review_title: I truly enjoyed working with my coworkers/managers
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newark, NJ
pros:
I worked at the Newark campus call center for almost two years as a student employee. I answered calls, greeted and redirected people in the lobby, and represented the organization at school events. The pros of the job are as follows:
-Flexible hours 
-Room for promotion/increase in hourly pay rate 
-The staff members are generally willing to help you with anything you may be confused about (except for financial aid office, they're not too helpful) 
-There is a strong emphasis on teamwork, meaning the work is usually split up evenly 
-As long as you communicate with the management, they are willing to adjust according to your needs (i.e. schedule change, day off, etc.)
cons:
-Sometimes shifts were understaffed. People would call out the day of, leaving more work for others. This happened fairly often. 
-Be prepared for a decent amount of angry calls regarding financial aid. The angry calls are almost always about that.
-The call campaigns are very tedious and 90% of the time, people either hang up on you or say they are already aware of what you called them about.

review_title: Bloustein School (Rutgers armpit )- a glorified arcane,  elementary school
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Can't think of a thing.
cons:
Demeaning, stupid, petty management who couldn't a run a lemon-aide stand,  nor survive in the private sector for a week, cannot hold onto their grants, becoming a lay-off slaughter house.

There is no job training allowed to advance skills out of thinking people will then quit with their new skills.

Clock-punching jerks  think productivity is measured by showing up less than 3 minutes late, not by qualitative contributions to cuts costs or improve work flow.  Their butt kissing spies will tattle if they see you grabbing coffee at Dunkin Donuts if not at lunch. 

Management will yell and scold at you in a meeting as though this were  parochial school class  in the 1960's.

You can only flex your hours once every 4 months, regardless of you changing life requirements or transit schedules.

Rutgers layoff policy is NO severance. You get some advance notice, but expected to work until the end to get paid. IOW, they rub you nose in it and they love doing that.

job_title: Graduate Assistant and Graduate Tutor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Really enjoyed the atmosphere and learned a lot from the students as well as my colleagues. The administration is fairly simple and not as bureaucratic with regards to our paperwork.
cons: The salary was never enough as a graduate student since my professor promised me $15/hour and I ended up with $12/hour. I was also abruptly replaced after the summer with no prior information. And, since the job was active in my profile with the university system, it was very complicated to remove that and get a new job at the same time. It did seem very unprofessional.

job_title: Part-Time Lecturer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Colleagues are very nice. It's easy to get there by public transit. Parking passes are very cheap (but traffic is a nightmare, so use the train!) Per course pay is decent compared to other universities. 

Most importantly, you have union representation. You will need it.
cons:
Everything about working here is a bureaucratic mess. You have to re-submit your entire job application every semester. They need your availability nearly a year in advance. They won't give you multiple sections of the same course in the same semester. Course Directors drag you in for constant, pointless meetings and micromanage your teaching. If you try to apply for tuition remission (which is a guaranteed element of your compensation in the contract) they will make you wait many months, reject the application, and make you go to the union to receive compensation. 

Office space is a joke (a closet with two desks shared by dozens of PTLs with a sign up sheet for desk time taped on the door). Classroom tech is often broken or missing.

Like most universities, there is virtually zero opportunity to move from part-time to full-time work.

review_title: Great... if you can get in
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
- Great supervisors who genuinely cared about their employees and students
- Excellent salary and benefits if you are lucky enough to get a permanent full-time job here
- You get to be part of a thriving research college environment that consistently hosts community-based events like Rutgers Day.
cons:
- In order to receive the aforementioned excellent salary and benefits, you must be designated a PERMANENT full-timer, not just a TEMPORARY full-timer. Sometimes, the HR office changes this status in the middle of the academic year without informing you.
- Rutgers is a large, well-know state employer so there are thousands of other applicants gunning for the same position. In addition, many supervisors already have a candidate in mind but they must still post the job listing online. Even if you are more than qualified for a certain job, it more than likely won't cut it. 
- In certain departments, there is no upward mobility so you need to find a new job in another department but then you run into the above problem.

review_title: Stay away if you are motivated and ambitious.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: 403b match is above industry standard.
cons:
It was disheartening to work at Rutgers. As a young professional, I was motivated to make a positive contribution and to achieve tangible professional growth on my job. I soon realized that it was impossible for a few reasons: 1. Archaic bureaucratic structure that prevents things from getting done. 2. Employees are not trained on proper protocols, thus causing a lot of confusion. 3. Mid-level managers are extremely incompetent. I had two director level supervisors above me, one had no vision and took credit for everything his employees did; the other one was constantly pissed off over nothing and took it out on junior level employees frequently. My workplace was like a war zone, I had to constantly avoid setting off grenades. 

The only bright spot was that our department's VP and AVP were amazing, exactly the kind of leadership that you would want for an organization. However, it was hard to tell if they knew what was going on behind the scenes due to their busy schedules. As a result, our department had a high turnover rate, pretty unprecedented for a university with relatively good pay, benefits and job security.

job_title: Co-Gen Operator in Piscataway, NJ
pros: some of the benefits to working for Rutgers, it is a stare job with state benefits...  it was not a difficult job and my direct supervisor was very nice.  The pay was not that great but being very close by and a good job it was worth it.
cons: some of the down sides to working for Rutgers was the people.  Some people were very nice , but 1 bad apple can spoil the whole lot of apples.

review_title: A gigantic bureaucracy that works (barely) in spite of itself
job_title: Associate Professor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Intellectual freedom, generally nice people.  A real community of learning, instruction, and research.  Most students are reasonably high quality.  Many excellent programs.  AAUP (professor's union) protects our jobs and intellectual freedom.
cons: Mind-numbing complexity, RUScrew, still clinging to in-person instruction.  Chronic staffing problems in the ORSP and DGCA offices hamper ability to obtain and manage grant funding.  As at any large university, money talks, and if you aren't bringing in enough grant funding, you cannot get anyone to listen to your ideas or get promoted.  As the flip side to the AAUP, the staffing unions have rigid word rules and make it difficult to hire qualified people and fire those who are underperforming.

review_title: Avoid, unless you don't have a choice
job_title: Part-Time Lecturer in Newark, NJ
pros:
I was given complete autonomy over building my classes and no supervision whatsoever when it came to actually teaching them. 

Theoretically, you could teach a full semester of courses and if nothing goes wrong you could earn maybe $30k/year if you did nothing else.
cons: Where to begin? Part-time lecturers received no benefits, no job security, and were grossly underpaid earning less than 1/3 of what full-time professors would earn doing the exact same work. When classes were assigned, PTLs were simply given the title of the course and that's it, left to fend for themselves in selecting a textbook, designing a syllabus, creating tests, and so on. There were no evaluations or supervision of any sort except impromptu student reviews at the end of the semester if students actually went through the effort to fill them out.

job_title: Student Worker in Newark, NJ
pros: Enjoyed working with fellow students in the office of admissions; overall "easy" job and very flexible with student schedules

job_title: Adjunct Instructor
pros: Apart from having to be physically present in class and for office hours, you have of flexibility in where and when work on other aspects of the position.. like class preparation.  Interesting and stimulation interactions with students both in term of class content and it application, particularly with maturer part time students who attend class after work.
cons: Poor pay - can be as low as $4,000 for full semester course.. Rigid deadlines in terms of class preparation, homework and exam grading and exam results submissions.  Need to maintain office hours. Time consuming grading if you are not assigned a TA.

job_title: Assistant Director in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Very innovative company, great benefits and paid-time-off, friendly environment and offers flexible work schedule for professionals.
cons: Frequently purchase new software for use by employees before the employees have a chance to adapt to the the latest one.  Employer does not include the users when making purchases of software .  This is critical to avoid many of the troubleshooting issues.  University is reactive an repeats the process the very next year.  This is an annual problem with advance and creates unnecessary audit findings.  As a result of this, employees spend countless hours working late or remotely (including nights, weekends and holidays).  Too many technology changes in a short period of time.

review_title: It can be a great place to work if you're under the right management
job_title: Business Specialist in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Your experience can really vary depending on what department you work in. My experience was not that bad because I worked under a very good business manager that ran the business side of the department very well. I learned a lot about grant management. If you have a positive attitude and treat people with respect, you'll do well. 

Benefits are also pretty good.
cons:
Some coworkers can gossip a lot and cause an uncomfortable work environment. 

Pay can also be on the low side compared to other universities in the tri-state area. Especially if you move around internally vs being hired from the outside.

Your experience will heavily depend on the department that you work in. This can be a bad thing because if the department is poorly run, your work life will become very unpleasant.

review_title: Great for students, not so much for staff
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newark, NJ
pros: Newark is up and coming, the students are wonderful, there's a lot of great things going on in the institution
cons: Upper management is totally inept on the administration side. Too much micromanaging and bureaucratic nonsense instead of true leadership. Good employees don't have freedom to do the work they want to do, and mediocrity is rewarded so long as "rules" are followed. For an institution that prides itself on being "family-friendly" and mentoring and meeting its students where they are in order to create future leaders, it sure doesn't walk the talk when it comes to employees. No room for growth.

job_title: Academic Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: They offer excellent salaries, and great benefits. for full-time employees.   Job security is good, owing to the unions.  Work-life balance is taken very seriously, even compared to other academic institutions.
cons: The administration is completely dysfunctional at basically all levels.  Extraordinary amounts of time, energy and money are wasted due to poor planning (or no planning), and failure to follow through on initiatives.  Critical decisions are routinely made at high-levels with little or no input from the employees that are affected, causing extreme stress and massive amounts of wasted effort doing fix-up/catch-up jobs that could easily have been avoided with better planning and implementation.

job_title: in Glassboro, NJ
pros: The only good thing Rutgers has going for it is there is a great work/life balance.
cons:
The senior leadership team at Rutgers-Camden is seriously lacking in management/leadership skills from the Chancellor on down.  Nobody is held accountable for actions that they take and they are only out for themselves.

Unfair treatment of employees runs rampant through the campus.  Certain departments are favored over others and are given preferential treatment towards salary increases and promotions while other hardworking individuals and departments are tossed to the side.  Someone should do an investigation into their practices for providing increases and disparate treatment.  The senior leadership all received over $200K in salary increases while others are denied or treated improperly.  

In addition, bullying from a senior manager happens on a daily basis.  And this individual is married to a senior leadership employee so employees are afraid to speak up for fear of retaliation.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Newark, NJ
pros: Excellent professional experience and a great opportunity to work with individuals who share similar passions in working with challenging children.
cons:
A very broken system:

I was extremely excited for the opportunity work at Rutgers UBHC and to serve the community of Newark (and surrounding cities).  Unfortunately, the department I worked in was notoriously mismanaged, as I heard echoed by every, single employee that I ever spoke to.  The most dedicated, educated employees often resign in a short amount of time.  That right there speaks volumes.  My heart breaks for the children and families who rely upon their services for help.

review_title: Great way to jump start a career in pharma
job_title: Fellow in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The Fellowship is a great way for PharmD holders to break into the pharma industry. Fellows often train under senior leaders in various depts, which can be the first step to a much stronger career than starting out from the bottom of the sales organization or in the call center
cons:
Some fellowships are better than others, and some partner companies are better than others. the best way to decide which position to go for is as follows: 
1. Traditional PharmD role VS more tangential? e.g. Medical affairs/Regulatory affairs VS competitive intelligence, marketing
2. Large, established company VS smaller newer company? (for the confident and/or prepared, go for the biggest best ones; for those with a weaker CV, go for a smaller company)

job_title: Associate Director in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Family-oriented flexible work environment, good benefits and a great team of staffers who are focused on doing their best. The administration has taken steps recently to show consideration  and appreciation for staff.  For instance during snow days  and classes are cancelled staff no longer has to report to work.
cons: There should be more structured opportunities for staff members to learn and grow outside of enrolling in classes at the University.   The tuition  remission benefit is only 50% once you earn a certain amount.  Parking is relentless and may times inflexible and punitive.

review_title: I am a PhD student who has worked as a teaching assistant and research assistant at Rutgers.
job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The professors I work for are very knowledgeable and organized. I enjoy the research I do and teaching students in lab classes. The career services at Rutgers are also very nice and helpful.
cons: I am personally not a fan of the location. New Brunswick is a town dominated by undergraduates, a lot of whom love to drink and party. Also, many of the students are not very motivated to learn, which can make teaching them difficult and tiresome.

review_title: Great Job for Students Looking to Earn Extra Money and Build Resume!
job_title: Peer Tutor in Cinnaminson, NJ
pros: Not too much commitment, depending on how many/which courses you tutor. You choose your hours and there is no minimum or maximum. Everyone is very kind and the Center for Learning and Student Success has great resources (whiteboards, tables, comfortable chairs). Very professional on-campus job. Can increase hourly rate by undergoing CRLA certification.
cons: None that I can think of! If you are looking to earn more on a consistent basis, consider tutoring high-demand courses like Calculus. Otherwise, tutoring demand ebbs and flows.

job_title: Learning Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: I was provided A LOT of training prior to working with my students, which I initially thought was very useless as I have held many jobs involving teaching others. I have to say, I never realized how complex the teaching process truly is. Not only is the training very beneficial, in ways that have actually helped me teach others in my daily life, but having so much responsibility for students was deeply validating too.
cons: You do have to take a class in order to become a learning assistant, which can be a pain if you have your schedule all planned out. It also requires some dedication and a solid understanding of your subject, as students will pick at everything they learn. I didn't mind this because it helped me understand my subject more and I grew as a person.

job_title: NOC Analyst in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Good stepping stone to start network career

Peers you work directly with were helpful
cons:
EXTREMELY political

Management is utterly clueless making poor decisions and doesn't understand technology and gives much higher raises dependent on whom they share a lunch table with. Furthermore, some of the staples in this department which management leans on gets overlooked during merit increases while Managers who have few subordinates reporting to them with limited knowledge on the technology receive raises 3 fold higher.

review_title: A good place to sit out an economic downturn
job_title: Java Developer in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Good vacation.  Good benefits.  Low pressure. Fantastic gym.If you are self motivated you can probably learn a lot by experimenting  in your free time.
cons: There is no plan.  Management decisions appear to be completely random and irrational.  Why buy off the shelf software for a few thousand dollars when you can hire a new department?

job_title: Instructor in Hoboken, NJ
pros: Fairly prestigious, well known institution, gaining more prominence nationally and internationally in the rankings.  While very political, not as dysfunctional politically as some other state schools (e.g., Kean).  Does seem to maintain its independence from Trenton and the fools that run the state.
cons: A huge bureaucratic place where politics looms large.  Each of the three campuses should really be a separate institution, as New Brunswick tends to be favored over Newark and Camden.  As should be expected, the politics of gaining tenure is huge.  Class sizes are often too large, but that's the way it is in many state schools across the country.

review_title: A fair place to work at
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Average salary, average benefit, basically everything is average. Nothing major to complain. As a postdoc, most of your experience is decided by your mentor, so choose wisely. Rutgers has a good location, close to both New York City and Philly. That's an definite advantage.
cons: Again, as a postdoc, your mentor has a huge impact on your working experience. The department and university don't have much control about that. So make sure you choose a good mentor. Another thing worthy noting is the housing is not cheap in that area of New Jersey.

review_title: Position is NOT what it is advertised
job_title: Field Service Technician IV in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Good benefits, most people are friendly (but demanding)
cons: Lousy pay, understaffed department, tech leads end up doing entry level help desk calls 95% of the time, no path for advancement, lack of adherence to IT policies and enforcement of rules causes every department to practice "IT free for all" where they will buy what they want without consultation from IT, and expect full support from centralized IT, lack of communication between medical school IT, hospital IT, and Rutgers core IT, place constantly has "no money" to spend on IT but we see money wasted elsewhere in abundance

review_title: I am a doctoral fellow at the New Brunswick campus
job_title: Doctoral Fellow in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Life as a doctoral student is really rewarding here. There are a lot of resources at Rutgers to help with research, writing, and presenting. There are also a lot of opportunities throughout the school that you might not get anywhere else. The campus culture is unique as well!
cons: Rutgers is a big school, and so it's easy to get overwhelmed and lost in all of the bureaucracy and politics. Fellows could be treated much better as far as benefits go. As of writing this review, fellows do not get the same healthcare benefits that TAs and GAs do.

review_title: Good university for graduate study and research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
I was lucky to work with a great professor and did my phd dissertation with him. Supported by the research assistantship, I was not required to work on other research projects but my thesis.

The health insurance plan given for the graduate assistants was very good. The spouses and children were covered too.

Parking is free for research assistants.

You can take courses up to 6 credits in the summer for free, as a benefit for a 9 month RA.
cons: The phone services were canceled, which was kind of inconvenient. Other than that, I enjoyed the graduate study there. The RAship is comparable to other universities nearby.

job_title: Project Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
-Stable employment - no one gets fired. If you get fired it's because you probably don't really know what you're doing OR a grant\some sort of funding ran out. 
-Good benefits - free gyms, pension is good, health packages aren't bad at all
cons:
- Inefficient, inefficient, inefficient and honestly Inefficient
- The staff side is draining - I work as a project coordinator in one of the large schools here and it seems like everyone just sits here to collect a check. Why? Because everyone knows nothing ever changes. Rutgers likes to hire but doesn't like to terminate. Especially the higher up you get. No matter how blatantly inefficient someone is, they are likely to be given a pass.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Newark, NJ
pros: The university has very high standards on research, good laboratories, libraries etc, departments are very strong, the groups are well connected with everyone you need to know in the world of academia. it's a good institution to have on your CV.
cons: As a postdoc you are basically a ghost. You don't have access to any of the benefits offered to staff and faculty like access to the gym. Only access to the library, that's it.

review_title: Well balanced work place, okay, but not amazing.
job_title: Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: It's a really well-balanced work environment, and work doesn't follow you home or take you overtime.  The people are generally great, and if you have a certain period of working time and class, the benefits are great.  The pay is also very decent for the location.
cons: There are a lot of loopholes in terms of Full-Time considerations that can earn benefits.  You can work Full-Time, but not be considered a Full-Time employee that can earn benefits which is a huge issue, and there's a lot of red tape and bureaucracy that slows processes down.  A lot of the employees tend to be recent graduates or staff that have been there a decade or two, so not much is updated.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: My department was flexible, and my supervisor was very easy to work with.  Expectations were clear, and everyone was professional.  Compensation was about average for the position, and benefits were good.  Business office was supportive and cooperative despite budget challenges.
cons: Working with other administrative offices was often challenging.  Failure of other offices to complete tasks made completing my own tasks very difficult.  Problems in bigger offices like HR and Payroll were difficult to fix and affected students and faculty in serious ways.  Lots of paperwork and red tape to contend with.

review_title: Great Place overall, but many not work for everyone.
job_title: Project Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Benefits - the best all around.  People are nice.  Great place for work life balance.  Job Security good.
cons: The cons may not apply if your not looking or groomed to be always under a challenge, but just want to do your work and a good job. Segregated co-worker environment - big negative.   Payscale is below average. Challenge is only for the few and not the many.  Little room for promotion since everyone stays past retirement.   Failure to provide vehicle for co-worker get together.

review_title: This is a state job position. Combines clinical activities, research, education.
job_title: Associate Professor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: This is a state job. There is some sense of stability. Many people are staying here for many years. There is an opportunity to teach medical students and residents, to do research, to get involved in clinical trials. Got sport facilities. Close to train station and 55 min from NY downtown by train. Many nice townships are around.
cons:
Low compensation, some beurocracy. It may take many month to get something approved.
We have had no salary increase since 2009. It does not look that things are going to improve due to dependence on state and decreasing funding from all sources (state, NIH, private funds)

job_title: Research Teaching Specialist IV in Newark, NJ
pros: Wow can't really find any accept that I liked most of my colleagues who by the way 99% of them have left the job
cons: Disorganized administration. We are wats given the run around because people do not know their jobs fully. The environment does not foster creativity. No opportunities for advancement. Old facilities everywhere including the elevators in which people are always getting stuck and which are never working. Employees are neglected and there are really no incentives to work there

review_title: Its a decent place for graduate study if you land with the right professor.
job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Close to NYC. They provide great health benefits for TA/GAs. The community is very ethnically diverse and welcoming to international students. Many departments are pretty decent if not great for graduate studies. However, it all depends on the professor you work with and the vibrancy of the lab. Lots of things to do in weekends- pretty decent bars and pubs. There are a couple of theaters and playhouses too.
cons: New Brunswick is not a very safe city. Certain parts can be dangerous at night.

review_title: Overvall a collegial and friendly work enviroment with alot of flexibility
job_title: Associate Director in Piscataway, NJ
pros: If you enjoy diversity  and a place that is open to work-life balance RU  is a great place to work.
cons: Change and advancement can take time. In certain areas RU lacks innovation. Sometimes RU treats its administrative staff as if they do not matter.  Sometimes RU beauracracy gets in the way of progress and innovation.

job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The benefits are good.  The ablity to learn more within ones position available and can be accessed through tution remission.  All of Rutgers is not the same when it comes to management and department culture...It varies with divisions and departments.
cons: Cronism culture is apparent within the department.  Some manager do not have a lot of responsibilities or hold enough skills to manage.  People who gets promoted do not get training for the promoted responsiblities in regards to management.

review_title: Great to start, great to join, not so great later.
job_title: Director in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Many chances for middle-management advancement and experience with software and hardware that may be difficult to gain experience with in a larger or smaller company.
cons: Silos and entrenchment. Usually faculty head departments and major positions. Because faculty are not managers, it makes it very difficult sometimes because they go from faculty positions to managing hundreds or thousands of people. Very little chance for advancement beyond a certain level.  Salaries have been flat with rising medical costs and inflation. As benefits erode, the bets people have and will leave.

job_title: Part Time Lecturer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I teach in the humanities.  It is very challenging work, and you have a lot of control over your own performance.  Rutgers' main pros may be a diverse student body and a large library.
cons: Pay for a PTL, even at a big university, is very low: on the order of 5K per course.  Most teaching (particularly early on) is intensive, and your per hour is low.  You also get last-choice in what courses you teach.  Classrooms vary from relatively sophisticated to muggy and cramped.  Students often unmotivated.  Department and university management (as it were) is uninvolved.

job_title: PhD Student in Newark, NJ
pros:
Academic community
Student community
Diversity
Resources:  Because they are a large university and many faculty there are lots of resources for both research and life. Also, being in a huge metro area there is access to many other institutions.
Support: Because they are a large university and many faculty there are lots of people to support you in your research.
cons:
At the time, salary only barely covered my cost of living.
Administration is not good at all. Many are very incompetent, and unhelpful. This is actually an understatement in the case of a few people I can think of. Sorry but it's true.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Newark, NJ
pros: Employees have a lot of atonomy to create and develop entire courses.  U.S. News and World Report consistently ranks Rutgers-Newark the #1 most diverse college campus in the country.  My students not only speak multiple languages, they are able to contribute experiences from their different backgrounds and upbringings.
cons: Rutgers-Newark is primarily a commuter's school. More interaction between faculty within, and from outside, the department would be productive.

review_title: Working as a Postdoc at Rutgers
job_title: Vision Scientist in Newark, NJ
pros: Rutgers offers a comprehensive benefits package to postdocs, including health, dental, and prescription insurance. The Newark campus is well situated and close to public transport and offers ample parking space for employees. Working environment is adequate, buildings are old, but maintained well-enough.
cons: At Rutgers Newark, postdoctoral salaries are not adequately matched to the cost of living in the area. The greater New York City area is expensive compared to the rest of New Jersey, and salaries should be adjusted accordingly.

job_title: Enhanced Classroom Support Student Technician in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Work was primarily with projectors and basic technology. Training was provided and each shift was very simple. Fair and competent leaders, as well as a fairly regular pay raise helped make this the ideal job for any college student.
cons: Pay started out near minimum wage but did not stay there long if you work hard and diligently. Sometimes the work is tedious and other times it can be quite stressful. In other words, work experience is not consistent.

review_title: The Learning Center was the most rewarding hourly wage job I've ever worked at.
job_title: Office Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: My duties included signing students in, answering the phone, and cleaning the dry-erase boards. None of those are onerous tasks. If was a particularly busy day, such as the days before midterms when lots of students come in for tutoring, then my shift would seem to go by very quickly.
cons: There are some days where there are no tutors working and no one comes in to study. I wasn't allowed to study at my desk, so those shifts were sometimes tough to get through.

review_title: Overall my experience has been challenging and rewarding.
job_title: Research Teaching Specialist IV in Rutgers, NJ
pros: Chance to work on exciting research opportunities, my workplace in particular is fast paced and has plenty of funding. Benefits seem comprehensive and there are perks to my PTO.
cons: Commute, work life balance is not always ideal, but that is more to do with the laboratory that I work in and not to do with the Rutgers as a whole.

job_title: Ph D Student/Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Big university (also a BIG TEN UNIVERSITY), various majors/subjects, many resources from different resource centers and faculties and stuff; Student Research Assistant Salary is relatively higher than similar universities in the same area. Good location to downtown New Brunswick and neighbor to New York City. Football is a big thing here. Very good employee benefits, probably the best in NJ.
cons: On-campus living expense is expensive. Some department have too many politics and are not put employee or student as their service priority. Many good faculties are leaving to better universities causing the interruption on graduate student's work and study.

review_title: Rutgers has been an excellent place to teach. The students come to class ready to learn, and are passionate.
job_title: Assistant Professor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The best reason to work here is the pay and benefits. The pay is very good, and the company provides excellent health benefits and time off.
cons: The promotions process is quite difficult. You may find yourself in the same position for some time. Also there are other problems such as parking that can come into effect. Could find yourself circling around a lot for a spot.

job_title: Peer Instructor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: My job is extremely flexible and my supervisors are kind and easy to talk to.  I enjoy the work I do very much, helping students master material is very fulfilling.
cons: The job does not pay as much as I would like, but overall I get payed handsomely for the hours I work.  I guess I would prefer more hours.  There is little room for growth unless you're interested in doing research as well.

review_title: Good place for your last postdoc.
job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in Piscataway, NJ
pros: If you are here you might end up with a supportive supervisor who understands that not every researcher wants to or is meant to be an academic researcher. You will have the chance to drop of your resume at one of the many companies within driving distance of Piscataway. Make sure you use labrat or biopharmguy as a search tool, do not rely on Indeed.
cons: Poor infrastructure, bad research funding, work environment can be primitive, e.g. our floor does not even have drinking water, we need to carry it in bottles from another floor. There is no sink to use other than in the restrooms.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: Very good pay, flexibility for vacation, freedom to pursue my own research. Postdocs were unionized during my first year and the results have been good, even if the union leadership is annoying.
cons: Some faculty members of the group are bad managers, mentoring not very highly valued.

review_title: Good while I was a student
job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I began working Rutgers as a masters student. Working in a research office in a university setting is really nice. My schedule was relatively flexible and the work was interesting and relevant to my future career path.
cons: When I finished my masters degree I asked my office for a small raise (I had been getting paid the federal work-study rate) and they said no. So I'm looking for employment elsewhere. Offices shouldn't pay graduates student rates.

review_title: Supportive and fast-pace work environment that wants you to grow and gain new skills
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I worked with a wonderful staff in quite a busy administrative office. I had plenty of contact with students and outside clients, and gained many transferable skills. The colleagues I worked with had years experience from all sorts different backgrounds and were willing to put all-hands on deck when things got particularly busy. They were really encouraging - if things got quiet, they would allow me to teach me new skills and gradually take on responsibilities that were slightly outside my role.
cons: Higher management changed frequently, but a short visit and introduction easily fixed that.

job_title: Learning Assistant in Rutgers, NJ
pros: Generally given a good deal of freedom with your lesson planning for study groups. Constantly meeting more undergraduates in your field as you teach them in recitation and/or study groups. Management is very involved in seeing you develop as a peer leader.
cons: Surprise evaluations can sometimes catch you off guard.  Sometimes there is not enough material available to efficiently make lesson plans; often, it takes a few hours at least to come up with something completely on your own.

job_title: in Newark, NJ
pros: With the right PI you can work on your own challenges and find ways beyond a normal postdoc experience. It really worth the effort, go for it.
cons: The big campus has an old structure, so most of the time it will be challenging to find solutions for the problems you have regarding the supporting staff or so simple things like the keycard for the door. You will learn to handle problems on multiple levels.

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in Newark, NJ
pros: Rutgers-Newark invests a surprising amount of resources into basic research. Several professors teach only one class a year, freeing up most of their time for research projects. As a postdoctoral associate,  worked directly with three faculty members and indirectly with several others, and it was useful that all parties were focused on projects.
cons: The infrastructure of RU-N is severely outdated. Many of the facilities are 20 years overdue for new construction, and the support staff is severely overtaxed. As with many post-docs, there is a lack of social structure within the research community, meaning you could go a full week without interacting with another human being.

job_title: Office of Information Technology in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Having worked at Rutgers a student, I found it to be very beneficial. I made a ton of friends and direct deposit meant I got paid quickly and easily! Never had discrepancies with my pay check.
cons: There is literally no HR for students. I know we don't need it as badly as full time employees but there were times when I found our lack of HR to be detrimental.

job_title: Graduate Student in Piscataway, NJ
pros: You have lots of opportunity to meet very smart, enthusiastic people who are experts in their fields. Whenever you have a problem or have a question related to your research just knock one of the doors.
cons: For a grad assistant a supervisor means a lot. Depending on their style, you may have to struggle with all the problems during your research yourself.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hillsborough, NJ
pros: Good pay, good health and retirement benefit.  .
cons: Every week there seem to be an announcement of a new VP or new Associate Dean.  There is way too much administrative overhead and not enough people to do the essential job.  Also, University did not honor the benefit of "free tuition" to my child even because his grades were not good enough though he was accepted, with scholarship offers to other peer institutions.

job_title: Assistant Professor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Rutgers provides faculty members with highly supportive environment for research. Faculty members usually receive their own research account from which they can use funds for research purposes. Rutgers also seeks to provide competitive salary and benefit programs.
cons: Rutgers is highly reputable in NJ, but not so much in other areas of the US. It should put more emphasis on external relations and reputation building, which will ultimately help to obtain more resources and revenues.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Paid well for around ~15 hours of work per week
Included funding for graduate studies
Teachers were generally very friendly and helpful
cons:
Sometimes you didn't get a say as to which class you would be assisting for, and getting little warning (eg at the start of the semester) as to which class you would teach
Having to deal with apathetic students or cheating students on rare occasion
A distraction from working on the research.

review_title: Good potential, but currently a bureaucratic mess
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Rutgers has exceptional research staff in a very broad range of topics
Rutgers embraces diversity more than any university I have ever seen. It is not just that they have a diverse staff, the atmosphere is very embracing and proud of it.
cons: The university recently merged with several other organizations. As a result, there are usually two or more people or departments doing the same job. This results in massive redundancy and confusion. Even the simplest things like trying to get parking for a student volunteer often takes months to navigate. It is a mess!

job_title: Registration Administrator in Merchantville, NJ
pros: Your co-workers, the work space and the  hours.  The people you work with and the place the work all make a difference.  The hours are set and there is never any weekends.
cons: The management structure, supervisors and bosses leave and they do not replace them for months.  Everyone in the office is expected to pick up the slack, even though nobody is trained to do that job.

job_title: Business Analyst in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
- Get to meet & interact talented & bright kids
- Free access to fitness center
cons:
- Non-collaborative culture 
- Staff, especially those in the helpdesk, condescend to you when you ask for help, yet lack the knowledge and expertise to resolve your problem 
- lack of transparency 
- slow to disseminate, sometimes critical, information 
- policies are unclear or unknown to employees because they are not accessible (they need to be posted online for easy access)

review_title: Poor department morale.  Employees overworked and underpaid.
job_title: Athletic Department Member in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The role to help make a student-athlete's experience a rewarding one.  Being involved in athletics.
cons: Compensation is very poor for every single phase of the department outside of football and basketball support staffs.  Every decision made has budgetary concerns, down to buying a pencil.  Best interest of the department as a whole is not the main factor in decision-making, money is.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Pros for being teaching assistance at Rutgers is that they have very good benefits, like parking and health insurance. The work as teaching assistance depends on different department, some of the department has relatively easy work than others.
cons: The cons is that teaching assistance are relatively low paid, and after tax, you probably will not get much. The teaching assistance in some department is really laborious.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros: Salary is decent, excellent benefits and time off.
cons: Management is terrible. They aren't able to take advice and make you feel stupid even if it was there mistake. God forbid if you speak up against the supervisors they retaliate and begin to single you out and make your life miserable. Morale in our location is at an all time low  but supervisors don't care. Even when you do you do your job well here and be right on-point they will still find a way to tell you it was wrong. Unless you are one of their favorites.

job_title: Alumni Relations in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Most of the people are great to work with and seem to be passionate about the students. I enjoy working on the campus and interacting with the faculty and students. Very vibrant community and there is always something to do on campus. Great opportunities for growth, although it can take time. There are great benefits, I would definitely  recommend!
cons: The pay is low and movement through the salary grades is a slow process.

job_title: Mid-Level Management in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Rutgers University is a great place to work and gives you access to many opportunities in various fields.   Working with students in IT keeps you familiar with technological advances.  Great benefits, especially for those looking to advance their education or have kids that are about to go to college.
cons: Rutgers is a state university and many jobs are funded by state budgets.  That means when the state encounters financial challenges, Rutgers employees may also be affected.  Also, employment opportunities at Rutgers can be hard to land with increased competition for any open position.

job_title: Business Specialist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Great hours if you are a working parent, Enough days to cover school closings and sick days
Great learning environment, opportunity to get experience in specific areas especially in not for profit. if you love learning, its a great environment
cons: Not easy to get promoted, the system is clogged with old timers just waiting their time out to retire, For a university, they tend to hire people without a degree a lot and at the same pay rate for the graduates. HR is not supportive of lower level employees, so a lot of managers get away with unethical treatment of employees.

review_title: A lot of help in finding an on campus job
job_title: Orientation Leader in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Because the school is so big, there are tons of places where you can try to find a job. Usually the pay under or near $10, but it is still something if you add up all those hours. Plus you get experience to speak about on interviews
cons: The job is not the most important thing you will do in your life. Usually it is some simple stuff like cleaning in dining halls or working with admissions on welcoming students. You can still learn from everything you do!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: Rutgers University has great facilities: autoclaves, lab equipment, etc.  Rutgers University Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences has a great faculty and curriculum.
cons: Rutgers University Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences is not in the best area.  I would say that the neighborhood is not that safe, so everyone always needs to be aware of their surroundings.

review_title: The Dean of Dental School Is a Real Problem
job_title: University Professor in Newark, NJ
pros: Easy work as professor. Not much else. Best advice is to stay home, or hide in your office. No one cares, as long as you do nothing and pose no challenge to managent.
cons: Dean and assistant deans are solely concerned with keeping their jobs. They let all top professors move elsewhere because they felt threatened. The real problem is that the Dean of the Dental School actually knows very little about dentistry or research. She only wants to preserve her job, unfortunately this harms all the citizens of NJ. She only wants to surround herself with people who know less than her, and that is pitiful. This can only happen at a state institution...

review_title: RWJMS - Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences PhD student
job_title: Graduate Student in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
100+ research labs to choose from
1 hour away from the Jersey shore, the Pennsylvania wilderness, Philadelphia, and New York City
New iJOBS career training program
cons:
I had little to no career advice while in the UMDNJ Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences.  Luckily they just received a 5 year BEST grant from the NIH to start the iJOBS program to address this.

As with any large university, it is easy to slip between the cracks unnoticed. Self-motivation and building an effective mentor relationship are both vital to not becoming a 7+ year graduate student.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great Science programs that are quickly growing. Good location, close to NYC, Princeton, PA, but away from the crowd. Very diverse campus, so no one feels like an outsider.
cons: Pay and benefits are not good at all. Graduate student offices in some departments have limited resources and technology. If using the bus system, during the semester it is inconveniently crowded by undegraduate students, and during vacations, it runs every 30-45 minutes, so a 5 minute commute becomes a 1 hour or more commute. Finally, Livingston campus is depressing. The New Brunswick area also needs to continue evolving.

job_title: Community Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Work on projects to improve lesson presentations that are researched base.  Colleagues are helpful. Tuition remission is the biggest perk.  Health benefit's are average but becoming expense in regards with percentage of compensation.
cons: Salary is low for the amount of outreach done.  Heavy micro management.  Salary employees are clocking in and out. High employee turn over rate.  Not supportive for employees looking to advance with-in or take advantage of tuition remission (some classes are in the morning or in afternoon).

job_title: in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Great people and benefits. I really do not have much more to say. Obviously I am not too pleased with the treatment even after being there for ten years.
cons: Upper management are completely clueless and back stabbing. The upper management in this institution would rather cover up other upper managements mistakes by taking it out on a lesser, then actually deal with the situation and make the proper corrections. In other words keep making the same mistake over and over, as long as it covers them.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: For a PhD student, the TA work at Rutgers is not heavy so I can save a lot of time on my own research and study. Also the salary is comparatively higher than any other school I know in the New York area.
cons: Also, for a PhD student, choosing a good advisor is an important key to the success in the graduate study. But the professors in Rutgers, especially in computer science department, are not sufficiently initiative and motivated. So, it's very hard for a PhD student to pursue a productive research experience here at Rutgers.

job_title: Business Assistant in Passaic, NJ
pros: Rutgers has easy hours, generous benefits package negotiated by the union, and a relatively transparent pay-grade system that can help you move up
cons: Rutgers has overwhelming bureaucracy that can sometimes make things move at a snails' pace. This very same bureaucracy can make it very hard to dismiss mediocre workers and to hire replacements.

job_title: Advisor in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Good job security, health benefits. Almost anything is possible when you work with Rutgers' brilliant faculty if they are properly motivated.
cons: Outdated central IT department. Far too many Chancellors, Vice Chancellors, and Deans, not enough mid-level skilled employees. Golden parachute contracts galore. Execs throw millions at administrators and contractors to solve problems like continuous DDOSes that can be solved by mid-range IT security specialists anywhere else. Did I mention the central IT department is outdated?

job_title: Lab Technician in Newark, NJ
pros: Working as a lab tech meant hr was never informed when I took days off so I got paid for my "unused" 2 weeks of vacation when I left
cons: The environment was terrible.  Upper mgmt/professors would work their employees and students to the bone while pinching pennies.  Buying the lab pizza for lunch once every 6 months was the extent of our perks and going to work every morning felt like walking into a funeral home.

review_title: The Island of the Lotus Eaters
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Decent salary considering minimal workload and low pressure environment.  Pleasant co-workers.  Good vacation, benefits (especially tuition remission), and athletic facilities.  Flexible hours.
cons: No one gets fired and no one gets promotions/raises so there exists a rampant pass-the-buck culture where there is no incentive to do good work.  Ambitious, smart people see this and move on, which leaves an underclass of Lotus Eaters - inefficient, apathetic people who have worked there forever.

review_title: Work Study Student at Mason Gross School of the Arts
job_title: Student Worker in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: In my individual experience at Rutgers, even as a small fish in a big pond, my hard work is appreciated. Also, I have built lasting relationships with my supervisors and peers which is an important aspect of my life balance.
cons: The department I work at is heavily outdated and could use a deep cleaning of the facility.

job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Good reputation in the area and highly skilled professors. Had several network events on Wall St where I had chances to meet professionals who actually working in the industry with industry expertise.
cons: The program was a one year long master's degree, which barely provide intern opportunities. Basically, you have to start to looking for job right after you have been accepted to the program.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Emerson, NJ
pros: I loved working for them. The student body is diverse and generally open minded. Great energetic place to work and great seminaries. Supportive and respect for individuality.
cons: In general, needs more energy in using the newest educational techniques. We can not keep teaching the same way when volume and breath of science has grown exponentially.

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
- Great Chemical and biochemical engineering department
- Location in New Brunswick, NJ area is ideal if you are looking to work in pharma-related field since a number of major pharma companies work in close proximity to the university
cons:
- Rutgers is a large university with 65k+ students, so it can get very busy at times. 
- The city of New Brunswick itself is relatively safe location to live; however, it is very important to choose which areas you wish to move in - since the safety level can chage drastically from street to street.

job_title: Dean's Office AV Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Plenty of opportunity.
Competitive environment.
NJ-lifestyle.
Multiple options to choose from if you don't have a car.
cons: Your experiences with Rutgers will vary a lot from where and whom you work for.  The embodiment of Rutgers University is independence and putting in yourself how much you want to get out of it.  Don't expect anybody to just help you; you have to do things yourself.

review_title: Nothing to scoff at, but not as "competitive" as they stated, either
job_title: OIT HelpDesk Consultant in Camden, NJ
pros: As a student, it's easier to work at the place in which you have classes. It also gives some interesting insight as to how the internals of your school works.
cons: HelpDesk consultants are basically in the dark about many things, and things are very compartmentalized so it's difficult to find the answer to even the slightest of complicated questions. Very unclear about employee advancement.

review_title: Working as a research associate at Rutgers
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Rutgers has great benefit such as a month of vacation time, low health insurance premium and generous 401 match. In addtion, most research positons have flexibile working schedule.
cons: Comapred with industry, research associates do receive relatively low salary. Otherthan that, I do not have much to complain but I have to meet the 20 work minimum limit.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros:
Lots of freedom, the ideal place to do pure math (in comparison to the horror stories I hear about the math department at NJIT). It's proximity to Princeton and New York city is an added advantage. The professors are excellent researcher. I wonder why would they choose to stay here, when I am confident they could easily move to a university with more Graduate students. 

Not only research, there is an ample amount of freedom in teaching as well. Great for work life balance.
cons: Not a lot of graduate students to discuss math.

job_title: Associate Data Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Overall good working environment with good benefits.
cons: There is none I can think of except for the limited Job offers and the non protection foe internal employee for job transfer within the Rutgers system.

job_title: IT Director in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Benefits, while diminishing are still excellent. IT has strong leadership and good values. You can make a difference in IT there.
cons: Bonuses and promotions are rare, so you must find employment elsewhere in the org to move up; silo-ism, administration turnover is challenging with some senior positions (Chancellors, deans, etc.). Higher education is in full disruption mode. Covid is an accelerator, but not the true cause of disruption. The world is changing, higher education is just discovering that! Faculty can be excellent, but also can be arrogant and selfish. Unions are difficult.

job_title: Unit Computing Specialist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The healthcare and dental benefits are great. They give ample amounts of sick leave and vacation time. If you are unionized, the job security is very good.
cons: The payscale for staff is a bit low in comparison to comparable jobs in the corporate sector. It used to be counter-balanced by a lighter workload and more flexible hours, but since the budget cuts the infrastructure has been damaged by loss of many workers and a lack of organization to compensate.

job_title: Research Programmer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The university culture is somewhat more relaxed than in the industry. Obviously, one's situation depends greatly on what department you are with. The benefits include access to resources such as the university library, recreational sports facilities, etc. Employees have access to a 457(b) retirement plan, which is a nice supplement to the usual 403(b) (which is a non-profit counterpart to the industry 401(k))
cons:
1) It's in New Jersey...

2) No matter how flexible and understanding your immediate management may be, there are also various university rules and polices, which sometimes help and sometimes hurt.

job_title: Graduate Fellow/GA in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Lots of diversity, access to almost any type of expert and you can find almost any type of equipment you need to do your research, generous pay for grad students, great selection of courses, lots of great amenities on campus like gyms with workout classes and campus events with free food
cons: lots of bureaucracy and paperwork, but if you know who to talk to to get what you need then you'll be fine

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: really good benefits, smart people, good colleagues. A lot of professors are really good and care about people, they have decent seminars too
cons: Too much administration and red tape. Also there are too many departments, which makes things really confusing for students and splits up money in odd ways. I am in a great department but it is poor and cannot fix equipment.

job_title: Rutgers Global Student Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The job is easy and the supervisors are very nice. You also get the opportunity to meet new people and build connections with them.
cons: The work can get very dry at times and there isn't much opportunity to move up.  The pay used to be very bad until Barchi upped the minimum wage to $11/hr.

review_title: Take advantage of the Free Tuition
job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
+ Free Tuition for undergrad classes
+ If you have a good manager who is educated in the field = you are set
cons:
-Grad study isn't completely free.
- If you are in a development position and your manager is a humanities graduate then you'll have a hard time getting things across. 
- Politics are an order of business some times.

review_title: Rutgers University is one of the most interesting places to learn and work.
job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
1.  Networking and knowledge sharing among coworkers is often just a matter of placing a call or asking a question and answers are right available.
2.Diversity often brings different perspectives to enhance productivity and efficiency
3.The availability of unending employees enhancement programs improve productivity.
cons: 1. Too much bureaucracy on job often reduces morale especially when a project needs urgent approval but it's being delayed as a result of bureaucratic approval.

review_title: Worst job I have ever had
job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Fairly flexible work hours; good benefits; good salary
cons: No communication from mid and upper managment; do not perform regular annual reviews; forget about any raises or recognition of good work; if you're in a non-union position you get no raises, no reviews, no potential for promotion - just horrible environment to work in; could be different in other departments/divisions

review_title: Your experience varies greatly based on what department you work in.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Outstanding benefits, vibrant location, diverse campus community, wide variety of cultural and academic offerings, solid support from administration, friendly and helpful staff
cons: The university is a large place to navigate causing some run around when you're trying to complete tasks, often the layers of bureaucracy get in the way of efficiently getting work done

review_title: Event staff- awesome part time work!
job_title: Event Staff in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I was part of the event staff during the football season. The majority of the staff there were students doing part time work or adults getting a little cash on the side. Everyone was very nice, we were trained for our roles and kept them throughout the season so it was very stable, and we were never asked to do things that we were not prepared for.
cons: Working outside during the winter has it's own set of challenges. Dealing with rowdy and intoxicated patrons can be difficult.

review_title: Great two years of working part-time for the New Brunswick Computing Services
job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Co-workers and supervisors are mostly friendly. You get the ability to learn more IT skills and rise to a supervisor position if you would like. It's decent pay for little work. This is probably one of the best paying job you can find as a student on campus.
cons: Some co-workers can be especially lazy and you may have to pick up the slack or risk being called out. It can also be annoying when they are consistently late for their shifts.

job_title: Lifeguard in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Flexible hours
work-study possible
free certification/training
accessible from campus

This twenty-word minimum from Glassdoor is unnecessary and irritating.
cons:
low pay
late-night mandatory meetings
sudden change in management uprooted superior/subordinate relationship

This twenty-word minimum from Glassdoor is unnecessary and irritating. There's not much to say. It's a part-time on-campus job, for crying out loud.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Good work/life balance. Good benefits and insurance plan. The adviser is friendly and helpful. The technical support works closely with the labs so that the lab instructors can work through the labs smoothly.
cons: The design of curriculum is out dated, which definitely needs to be modified so that students can get an up-to-date exposure to the knowledge.

review_title: Too complex for a simple (single) rating
job_title: Program Manager in Newark, NJ
pros: There is so much going on within a single university that the opportunities are countless. There are many talented people.
cons: There is so much going on in so many different places--which has grown locally, haphazardly, with no coordination across the institution--that even when you figure out how to get something done, it's inefficient, horribly time-consuming, and may be an entirely different protocol the next time you want to do that same thing.

review_title: A Chance to use my degree
job_title: Part Time Lecturer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: There are plenty of reasons to work at Rutgers.  One of the more prestigious University systems in the country, it manages to straddle being a state school with more of a feeling of an Ivy. And for me, it is conveniently located.
cons: As a part time lecturer, you do not qualify for full time worker benefits, such as health care.  My department loves my class, but only needs it once a year. So I'm forced to cobble together other teaching work elsewhere.

job_title: Research Assistant in Bridgeton, NJ
pros: Worked as a research assistant on one of the university's farms. Learned a lot and networked. Management really cared about personal interests and career advancement after college.
cons: There were not any real downsides during my contract. My positive experience may be mostly attributed to the Dr. I worked for, but most of the faculty I met seemed equally friendly and professional.

review_title: The people are very nice and it's a great way to meet people.
job_title: Fitness Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Great place to work if you go to the gym a lot.
The people you work with are young, so it's great for college students to get to know each other.
Make new friends that you know go to the gym.
Recreation center often gives out freebies that are awesome.
cons:
People are messy and you must lug weights around that people don't place back.
You get paid minimum wage at first but it's expected of a college job.

review_title: Generally good, but what's important is that your advisor/supervisor
job_title: Teaching Assistant/Graduate Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Overall, the environment is good. People are nice and easy going.
There are generally very helpful staffs except for some occasional bureaucracy.
cons: As a graduate student (part time employee TA/GA), your advisor/TA boss etc has great influence on how your life would be like as they have the utmost authority in the system regarding what you need to do. So luck is important sometimes. If you end up at an unpleasant place, it might be worth considering getting something changed.

review_title: The University is on the rise!
job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great benefits, lots of momentum after joining the Big Ten, exciting development of campus infrastructure and programming, attracting lots of new talent in many departments.
cons: It's a very big place and can sometimes be difficult to make personal connectuons. You run into some bureaucracy when dealing with multiple departments but that is to be expected at a large state university.

job_title: Applications Developer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
A good place to work, decent benefits (especially tuition for me and my kids)
Friendly and stable work environment
Lots of open spaces
Make sure to take advantage of events happening in or around campus
cons:
Pay is lower than private industry
Slow to respond to changes in technology 
People tend to fall into the 'we have always done it this way' mindset

job_title: Tutor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: There is a hugely diverse student body whose needs are impossible to account for so they are always looking for help.
cons: The pay is not great, I could make way more money working as a freelance tutor. They should pay tutors double what they pay them now.

review_title: The best part about my job was my boss
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I TA'd for the school of management and Labor relations as a Finance in HR and a Compensation & Benefits class. It was pretty flexible and I was able to learn so much due to the fact that the professor I worked with really cared about his students learning
cons: Most of the time, the students are lazy and it shows

job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Rutgers has been my best employer thus far. Avantages here include high standards for a work product that is comparable to any corporate environment, work/life flexibility, atmosphere of openess and respect, and lots of training and educational opportunities. As of now, benefits and vacation time are excellent.
cons: Compensation could be better, but tuition is waived for dependents. Have to pay for parking. Rutgers is a large place, so experience varies greatly based on your department.

job_title: Regional Nurse Administrator in Newark, NJ
pros:
Excellent benefits package.
Unlimited educational and professional development resources.
cons:
Position is grant-based and employment status is tenuous for such positions.
Following the filing of LEGITIMATE complaints to the Corporate Compliance Hotline, this employee has been targeted by administration and currently works in a hostile and retaliatory environment.

review_title: The best place to work if you need flexability and benefits
job_title: Senior Administrative in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Schedules and paid time off are very flexible. The benefits are tremendous.  There are many jobs in many different departments so the needs of this employer are varied and many.
cons: Each department has their own budget and not all departments have the money for computer equipment and training.  Forced to be in a union for certain positions

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: My supervisor is very good. She provides me with all the necessary assistance I need to do my work. The compensation is not bad but I believe there is more room for iimprovement
cons: The volume of work is heavy.  I am a TA for a class of about 150 so you can imagine the volume of work. Grading of mid-term, home work and finals is a headache. But a believe it's a very good school

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Biomedical Engineering
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Rutgers is a large university in the center of the biotech/pharma corridor which was great for providing opportunities for industry collaborations during grad school
cons: As with other large schools I've been at, there are always administrative issues, however these tend to be department specific.  I was cross-functional across the chemistry and BME departments, and I can tell you that the BME  department was a lot more helpful when it came to the HR aspects of being a graduate student.

review_title: Good way of studying and teaching
job_title: Lab Instructor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I am currently a student at Rutgers so there is no much pressure to teach. And the coordinator will not press you too hard on first time teaching. So it is a great place to learn things.
cons: The working hours are somehow long compare with the salary. Every week you need to spend a long time just to prepared for one section.

job_title: NBCS Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Learn customer service skills and computer troubleshooting with little prior experience.
Various promotion opportunities  Generally a good atmosphere to work with fellow students.
cons:
Sometimes it takes everyone to get the job done and not every person hired is a team player or knowledgeable in troubleshooting.
Management can be somewhat clicky but are easy to get along with.

review_title: A lot of jockeying for position
job_title: Program Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
