pros: The University has a nice campus and there was a certain amount of tuition remission.  The benefits were good.  There was ability to advance your career.
cons: While there was ability to advance your career, it really depended on who you knew and how much extra work you took on.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Very collegial culture.  Respect is geven by virtually all faculty whom I have encountered.  The Student body is composed of intelligent, disciplined and very respectful young men and women.
cons:
The Budget is always a challenge, so programs that could serve the students are occasionally limited to address this issue.  
Part Time Lecturers are not offered benefits package.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Worked with great people, had great bosses, and was always outside walking around so it made exercising and losing weight very easy.
cons: Rainy days were really boring. Spent majority of the day surfing the internet and playing on my phone because there was no work to do when the weather was bad.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: One of the best paying jobs on campus and can sometimes be fun. The Rutgers bus makes a stop there so no need for outside transportation.
cons: A lot of pressure to be persistent with people on the phone. Stressful trying to secure gifts and a lot of pressure from management to perform.

job_title: Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Majority of people are nice; good schedule; students are prepared and eager to learn; flexible hours
cons: The program itself is kind of a mess; there is no structure, and the program essentially feeds off of other more successful programs; this creates a logistical nightmare; it's hard to know what is going on; and the web site is so disorganized it's hard for students to know what the program is; the position is also part-time but is not really part-time

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great benefits, time off, flexible scheduling and down to earth, helpful coworkers.
cons: Salary isn't very competitive though the benefits make up for that in some ways. Too any layers and hard to get things done.

job_title: in Annandale, NJ
pros:
- Good experience for credit
- Learned how to manage University's large scale social media presence
- Able to participate in campus wide events and sample campus views/opinions
- Collaborated with video team and other social media management interns
cons:
- Unpaid
- Had to take online course and write essays/paperwork in order to get credit for internship
- Sometimes challenging to engage with unwilling/unenthusiastic campus community

job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Good environment with nice faculties and staffs, university offers affordable but still decent health and dental plan, available university housing is spacious and convenient, plus free access to all gym facilities.
cons: Relatively low compensation. But considering this is a job for graduate student pursuing an advanced degree, it is still acceptable.

job_title: Associate in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I worked on campus, where I also went to school. The job was easy and paid minimum wage, so I could afford to live in the nicest cardboard box in the whole dump!
cons: When I came home I smelled like the food I was working with. I only got around 10 hours a week so I couldn't afford the second box I really would have liked to keep all my hypothetical extra possessions in.

job_title: Professor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great job great people great location the benefits and salary are decent could be better but it is ok compared to similar universities through the united states
cons: upper management needs a clear vision decide what type of focus the administration wants to follow like research education community support and increase visibility in this area to build a better brand

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Rutgers University provides a very friendly work environment for its Graduate Assistant.
cons: Taking excessive amount of courses at the same semester you work as GA might be a little overwhelming

review_title: School is too big, some small things can take a long time
job_title: Postdoctoral At Rutgers in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Employee get certain good benefits, include good health insurance package, and dependents tuition waiver to go to Rutgers. Work life balance is great.
cons: School is too big, some small things are hard to get done quickly. Salary is low.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Edison, NJ
pros: Flexible hours for students, full timers not so much. You can come in early and leave early however as office is open for about 10 hours. Supervisors are amazing and job is pretty laid back and employees are fun to work with as well.
cons: Good amount of standing and walking especially in the back warehouse. Its not too bad as you can listen to music while you work. Wont notice how fast time will fly by.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Rutgers was a good place to be a graduate assistant.  They tried to make sure people had funding while they worked there.
cons: issues with limited funding could get frustrating.   You sometimes got the feeling that the school cared more about the football team then they did about you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newark, NJ
pros: Great benefits, opportunities to learn both in formal coursework and on the job.  Lots of opportunity to show what you can do.  Stellar benefits, generous paid time off.
cons: Constrained budgets and archaic funding and business models can prevent good stewardship of university resources, internal politics can be frustrating. Tradition (resistance to change) sometimes trumps innovation.

job_title: Aresty Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: It's one of the only research assistant programs to pay at Rutgers, and it's run by staff that make sure you don't get screwed over by crazy professors
cons: The meetings with your Peer Instructor are basically useless and can take place at really inconvenient times. For the second semester I had meetings at 8:30am

job_title: Research Coordinator in Newark, NJ
pros: the benefits sick time and days off.
cons: Overworked daily. Not enough resources to complete a job . Have days without even taking lunch . Pay is average. Management is horrible. Everything is unorganized. Patients are used as a cash cow.

review_title: It was good but not much room for growth.
job_title: Student Ambassador in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: It was close to me. Positive work environment with great co-oworkers.  Fun, social environment at work which makes the job less miserable.
cons: The pay was not very good for the work I was doing.  Not much room for growth and an immense pressure to perform.

job_title: Tutor in Newark, NJ
pros: You are in charge of what hours you work. There is a great feeling you receive when you are able to help a student.
cons: You may come across students who don't want to do any work. It takes time to earn their trust and eventually they begin to open up.

job_title: Talent/Human Resources in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: 9 to 5 job - leave on time.
cons: Many corruptions and injustice by management across the board. You have to know someone or be a very good puppy in order to be part of the management team. Lots of favoritism and lack of leadership. Management has no idea what is going on nor care. Moral is very low and many unhappy employees. Everyone is afraid to speak up in fear of retaliation. Don't work here!

job_title: Senior Financial Aid Officer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Prestigious University. Lots of diversity among staff and students. Good work hours, great state benefits. Use of wonderfull facilities. Tuition Remimbursment for self and children.
cons: Large University and office, so many working parts which entails bureaucracy. Upper management staff didn't listen to employee concerns. Lots of work, needed to increase staff size to accommodate increase in Student enrollement.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Good working environment. Coworkers work well in a team, making the role of being a TA much smoother.
cons: If the professor teaching the class you are a TA for is well-organized, it makes the job easier. If not, it can be difficult projecting how much work you will have per week.

job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Very flexible hours allowing you to work potentially as much as you want, or as minimally as needed if classes become too much and need a small break. The people you work with, the supervisors and other consultants, are also amazing and really fun. Low stress and high paying for what is asked.
cons: Sometimes scheduling may not fall in your favor and you may get less hours than you want.

job_title: Professional Staff in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Respected university, excellent faculty, nice and hard working colleagues, relatively good salary.
cons: Understaffed in critical areas, terrible management, very low morale (in my department, the lack of support from management led to very high turnover). I had relocated to NJ for this job and I lasted just over a year because the environment was absolutely unbearable. I left at great personal expense, but my mental health was more important than the money. Overall, a very disappointing, demoralizing experience.

review_title: Teaching experience of a part time instructor
job_title: Part Time Lecturer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Topi tier research university - prestigious
Great boost to CV
Internationally known scholars
Collegiality
Great students
cons:
HIgh stress
Widespread campus
Not enough space for part time instructors' offices

review_title: Limited opportunity for advancement after Senior Business Manager (think Senior Analyst/Project Manager)
job_title: Senior Business Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Staffing is very lean which means that there is low risk of being let go.  The benefits are excellent... match on 403(a/b) of more than $1:$1, inexpensive health benefits.
cons: Low salary and virtually no way to be rewarded outside of very strict (and small) merit increase pools allocated to the units.  Terrible financial systems results in a lot of low-value, manual work to produce simple reporting.

job_title: Learning Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Strengthens your understanding of the subject and there is no better feeling than realizing that you have helped a student understand something that was previously confusing.
cons: Takes a lot of time. Need to plan lessons in advance and the supervisor is very strict about administrative issues.

review_title: Pretty good place to be a TA
job_title: Graduate Assistant/Teaching Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The availability of TA positions for grad students varies by department but is good in the sciences at least. Pay is competitive with other schools, and the health insurance was very good at a reasonable cost.
cons:
There is always red tape to getting anything done.
Grad students are the bottom the food chain. You're formally above undergrads, but since they're paying to be there and you're getting paid, everything is designed around them.

job_title: Student Employee
pros: Great staff and environment. The end of the year student appreciation days are always fantastic and enjoyable.
cons: For all the money that goes into UCS they could absolutely afford to pay their student workers more. Most of us are in at least 15-20 hours a week and are assigned tasks on the level of graduate students or even full time employees. For that we should definitely be paid more

job_title: Part-Time Lecturer in Newark, NJ
pros: Rutgers pays their adjuncts better than many other schools. The diversity of the student body is exciting.
cons: There is absolutely no teacher training. Many events are held when the adjuncts can't attend because they're overwhelmed with work, so the position can be lonely and doesn't allow for networking or advancement.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Rutgers is a very comfortable place to work. Hours are standard-clock in/clock out at the same time-sort of deal. Benefits and PTO are outstanding. It is full of paper-pushers who want to collect a paycheck every two weeks without having to work hard. That's not necessarily a bad thing, it depends on your personality type.
cons: There is no sense of urgency. This is not the work environment for the go-getter.

job_title: Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Ability to input the hours you'd like to work, can schedule around classes and other engagements. Ability to learn many hard & soft skills in a comfortable environment. Can do schoolwork or study while on duty (as long as responsibilities are managed).
cons: Not much flexibility or cohesiveness between locations across campuses.  You are bound almost entirely to your specific Lab.

review_title: Opinion based upon short period of time there
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I enjoyed the quality of my co-workers, the university's reputation, the facilities and resources, and the work content.  I wish my personal circumstances had been different, and that I had stayed on.
cons: In my particular situation, there was a mis-match between my direct manager and myself, which is certainly not a factor involving the University. We both could have handled it better than we did.

job_title: Receptionist for Dean of Students in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: There was a decent amount of flexibility with the scheduling. You had enough idle time to work on other things if you needed to.
cons: They didn't provide me with much training, and as a result, I ended being reprimanded for things I was not trained to deal with. I eventually caught on though

job_title: Peer Advisor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: As a student they worked with your schedule and created a professional environment to prepare us for post graduation jobs. Busy office because of how much Rutgers students are involved with their clubs.
cons: Could be a bit overwhelming at some points that felt like it was completely student run office, but seek for help and help others.

job_title: Marketing Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Co-workers and superiors are very pleasant and agreeable as well as forgiving. Work is manageable and consistent. Opportunities for self-directed projects always feel available, and I am given plenty of freedom when choosing how to approach a task.
cons: Disorganized management structure. Weekly staff meetings felt pointless, with very few people actually giving weekly reports and people skipping meetings without saying why. The department required submission of BOTH daily and weekly timesheets to different supervisors.

review_title: dynamic, diverse, rewarding life studying and working at Rutgers
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Rutgers is a comprehensive, multi-disciplinary university. There are lots of opportunities to learn and interact with people from different backgrounds. Plenty of resources out there.
cons: Due to the economic crisis, the University has some difficulty in managing the budget. They cut extensively the research funding, resulting in funding shortage in many laboratories.

review_title: Working at Rutgers is truly a very rewarding experience.
job_title: Office Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Coworkers are very friendly and cooperative.  The environment is a positive one and people care about what they do.  Helping students is always the number one priority.
cons: The pay is a bit low, but I enjoy the job, which makes the situation positive.

job_title: Assistant Lab Supervisor in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Flexible hours, relaxed work environment, great in learning both technical and leadership skills, competitive pay with other student jobs
cons: Variable work means that some days/shifts are quite difficult and others are easy - with student workers, not everyone is very committed to the position

job_title: Assistant Director in Camden, NJ
pros: A great place to live and work, plus 5 minutes from Philly. Working with so many non-traditional and first generation college students was incredibly fulfilling. Pay for my position was vastly better than others in similar roles at other institutions.
cons: People stay working there for life, so it can be hard to advance. Normal bureaucratic complaints- everything is slow.

review_title: Good job but Coronavirus killed it
job_title: Dining Services Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Good salary, great benefits, 45 hour work schedule weekly, fun to work with students
cons: Employees are part of strong union, dietary restrictions/allergies for students is demanding and you are held accountable for any issues with that.

job_title: in Newark, NJ
pros: Great people who have a vast background in many fields that can actually hold an intelligent conversation.  Work environment is cultured.
cons: Longer hours of commitment is like any other job that has to be fulfilled through time and schedule.  Need to have a life.

review_title: Welcoming environment with flexible part-time hours
job_title: Professor Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: As a professor assistant, hours are extremely flexible, and job satisfaction is generally contingent upon the specific professor with whom you are working.
cons: If you are looking to fill in a large number of hours, it can often be very difficult to justify a great deal of work.

review_title: Relaxed working environment with governmental benefits
job_title: Lecturer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Job security: you won't get fired unless you do something really wrong.
Relaxed work: It's a public university, so you know that most people don't work overtime.
Good work/life balance: free admission to university properties such as Gym.
cons: The University is large and governed by the board. It's often hard to change things because they have to go through many processes.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Tutoring my fellow students at the writing center widened my exposure to the many classes for which they sought help. This exposure piqued my interest in several subjects enough to pursue a double major and minor in very different fields.
cons: It's difficult to get a job with the university unless you know someone. I know this is often the case at many companies but it seems more prevalent in certain departments at Rutgers.

job_title: Learning Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Good pay, really enjoy teaching recitation and working with students to further their understanding of the fundamentals of Computer Science.
cons: It's a public institution, so there's a decent amount of bureaucracy involved. If you're willing to put up with it, it's not a bad place to work.

job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The University offers a great number of opportunities, particularly if you are searching for stability.  Further, employees are encouraged to avail themselves of resources throughout the University for personal enhancement or edification.
cons: The support staff can make or break your experience.  Management is very tolerant, which, while quite nice in many ways, makes life difficult when it comes to payroll processing.

review_title: need to be strong in information technology support for research
job_title: Programmer Analyst in Newark, NJ
pros: the benefit at legacy Rutgers is better, a well renowned university.
cons: benefit at legacy UMDNJ (University of medicine and dentistry of new jersey) is not good enough, especially regarding the Educational assistance/tuition assistance, cannot afford even one course for advanced degree program.

job_title: Student Worker in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
They were very flexible with my hours. 
Always offer to include you on things going on around the campus. 
Very friendly.
cons:
Boring. They didn't have a whole lot for the workers to do. 
There was usually more workers than there needed to be.
Depending on which office you work at, the area was pretty small. 
Show favoritism toward the older students that have been working with them depending on which office you work in.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbia, NJ
pros: Worked with very bright people. The size of the University and its many affiliates provide many opportunities for intra- and interdisciplinary connections. Felt like I was getting a very fair deal through tuition reimbursement and the experience was invaluable.
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Relaxed atmosphere with little stress. The job was simple and it was just a part-time gig, and the people were nice.
cons: The work was pretty tedious, it was mostly data-entry but this was the task that was expected from the beginning.

job_title: Research Scientist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Excellent staff and opportunities to learn on the job
Access to many good research libraries
Supportive coworkers 
Good work environment
cons:
Difficult to go from non-tenure track to tenure track position once hired
limited autonomy in group setting
academic salaries are lower than industry
Could have more opportunities for internal hiring

job_title: in Rutgers, NJ
pros: Rutgers University provides a lot of opportunity to students to have a part time job while having a full schedule of classes.
cons: There isn't much training available for situations in terms of dealing with customer calls. There is also not a lot of available hours to work.

review_title: The part-time job that I had at the company that is Rutgers was fantastic.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Rutgers is that they are very understanding of students and the work load that they possess.
cons: I wish that I was paid more at this job. The pay was low, but the experience was great.

review_title: Working at the computer labs was a very rewarding experience.
job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: You gain valuable customer service skills. You help students with technical problems. You learn something new about different software. Many opportunities to advance. Flexible hours, you basically choose your shifts around your schedule at the beginning of each semester.
cons: Repetitive training sessions each semester. You may encounter some pretty upset or ignorant students who think they are entitled to not follow lab policy.

review_title: Good family life, slow career growth
job_title: Applications Developer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
You can
1- Focus on your family
2- Get tuition remission for your further education
3- Enjoy Rutgers facilities (libraries, recreation centers, dining facilities)
4- Great place to work for women
cons:
1- Slow career growth
2- Existing staff does not want to adopt new ways of doing business
3- Pay is less than what you can get in corporate sector

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Excellent benefits, including tuition remission for you and your children. Good job security and many career options.
cons: Staff salaries are very mediocre for NJ.  Very bureaucratic; fragmented environment that lacks any sense of community.  School is not very progressive as far as implementing innovative staff development programs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Nice environment. A lot of very smart people. Access to tons of university facilities. Autonomy. Able to learn a lot while contributing to important projects.
cons: It's in New Brunswick, NJ. Not much to do in the town and not many nice areas to live around there. Very large and  bureaucratic.

job_title: Resident Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Easy tasks and face to face interaction with interesting clientele. Free Housing for the duration of your employment.
cons: Bad schedule, One will always have a weekend shift and one shift where you stay overnight. The pay is a stipend to a Rutgers only account, and the current management will micromanage extensively.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Rutgers University has many researchers and great core facilities for good research.  Many of the researchers here have decent grants.
cons: The university is large  and when you have a problem, especially human resource related it is difficult to find the correct person to help you.

review_title: It is not boring but not exciting though
job_title: Grader in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: A good school that you can learn many things the working environment is fine and people there mostly are nice.
cons: New Brunswick is not too prosperous and there is limited chance to network. Also, safety is not guranteed given there are lots of crime alerts.

review_title: Not happy with this place.  Don't come here
job_title: Ph D Student/Research Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: Opportunities to work closely with surgeons
cons: Too much red tape and politics in everything that is done here.  The Newark location (formerly UMDNJ) is falling apart, and at this rate, it seems like it will likely be shut down soon.  This will leave many people without jobs.  They have already let go of many people who have been here for a long time.

job_title: Information Technology Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The sheer size of the public university allows for plenty of opportunities for growth, through lateral movements to other areas/departments and promotions.
cons: For a public university, the salaries are subpar when compared to corporate industry and also to peer institutions.   Also, room for growth is minimal in smaller departments.

job_title: Operator Engineer in Acworth, GA
pros: there benefits was very good the people that i work with were the best every day was a day of learning.
cons: there is not much that i can say about this company but some time they have to listing to there workiers

job_title: Dining Services Student Worker in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Had a lot of fun with coworkers while preparing foods. We were able to eat dining hall food at a discounted rate. Scheduling was very flexible to work around your classes.
cons: Not as organized as it could have been. Supplies often were not available and it slowed down production progress. Also, the pay was not ideal.

job_title: (Student) NBCS Computer Lab/ResNet Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
- Continual training
- Yearly raise with possibility of additional merit raise
- Relaxed supervisory staff and excellent co-workers
- Non-stressful work environment, open communication with upper-level management
- Great networking opportunity for full-time employment post-graduation
- Excellent promotional opportunities if you're motivated
- Extremely flexible scheduling with ample opportunity for extra hours if you desire
cons:
- Troubleshooting issues can be repetitive 
- Very hectic intervals between class changes followed by long lulls

review_title: I work as a part-time employee for Rutgers as I have been pursuing my Bachelor's Degree.
job_title: Sales Associate in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The pay is decent, students study on the clock, there is paid lunch and the hours are very flexible.
cons: There is a lot of politics among colleagues, the staff expects student employees to work just as hard as full time employees.

review_title: Livingston Dining Commons Dining Service Assistant
job_title: Dining Service Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The hours are pretty flexible. The student managers and the student staff are really friendly. Livingston Dining Hall is the best dining hall on the entire Rutgers University.
cons: You needed to use a meal swipe to get into work, or they would have deducted money from your pay check. Lots of physical labor in an unpleasant environment (dirty dishes and utensils in kitchen, very hot and humid).

review_title: Lots of variety of salaries among Rutgers schools for the same titles - RU should work toward standardization
job_title: Administrator in Newark, NJ
pros: lots of job opportunities and many different types of academic programs and administrative and student services
cons: RBHS, which used to be UMDNJ - the central admin employees are being laid off with more to follow, I assume

job_title: Intern
pros: Never a shortage of work experience. There is always something to cover in the School of Environmental and Biological Sciences. The role served as more of a copywriting position to market the university's research goals. I learned quite a lot about editing, making deadlines and the general discipline required to work in an office setting.
cons: None. Not for those who are afraid of technical topics.

job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The professors are very helpful and allow freedom to pursue research in your area. There is also less restrictions to spend time on course work and more time on the research
cons:
Graduate students are incompetent and don't work hard enough.
Course work is too simple and don't learn much from it.

job_title: Business Ambassador in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: You can work at your school while attending it. Also you are working with the deans and advisers and other important people who can help you. The job was basically a receptionist for the deans where you would transfer calls and also direct people who came in to meet with them. The job was easy going but got busy during important university days.
cons: I was working while taking classes.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The salary is exceptionally low but it is a great way to gain experience for later in your career.
cons: Many of the students are unmotivated which can make effective teaching difficult. They are entitled and seem to feel that they are owed a good grade by simply showing up.

job_title: Help Desk in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The coworkers you work with are exceptional. Management also has the back of their employees and they do what they can do help you succeed. Good salary for the work that is done.
cons: Rutgers University is a large organization and as a large organization it can occasionally be difficult to get timely responses from other departments.

job_title: Tutor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: flexible hours, good location, good managers, easy work, paycheck system was reliable and easy to use, easy to communicate with higher-ups.
cons: low pay, the instructions and methodology for tutoring aren't always effective, sometimes difficult to communicate with students who come in for tutoring

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Very, very nice people to work with. Most people take their job seriously. Nice not to work with slackers or people who take advantage. Everyone works hard.
cons: Little mentorship going on. Must get the scoop on how to advance from others and let that be known to your advisor/supervisor.

job_title: Residence Life Coordinator in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Good benefits, decent salary, lots of discounts, free tuition
cons: Leadership in the department of residence life is heartless and cares about nothing but money. Employees are second hand citizens to them and they see everyone as replaceable.

job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Big campus, relative high salary, beautiful campus, very good gym with Olympic standard pool for guys who love to swim,
cons: Boss is tough but might only in my case, the quality of faculty could be higher and there are not too many aggressive professors

job_title: Desktop Support in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I was fortunate enough to work in a department that had hard working co-workers and understanding upper level supervisors.  Laid back environment but work and projects were still completed accurately and in a timely manner.
cons: Pay was low especially if you're a student worker whether you're an undergrad or a graduate student.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Loved it because of that fact that the jobs require being and sociable person therefore everyone there is that.
cons: You can be over worked sometimes and wonder if you are actually appreciated.  Sometimes things are done to offset this feeling though.

job_title: Building Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Opportunity to work with fantastic people who all genuinely love what they do. Pay is great as well.
cons: There were a lot of inter-office politics and red tape (typical throughout Rutgers) which was really frustrating. Communication across different levels of management sometimes seemed to be lacking as well.

review_title: You better really like the work
job_title: Staff III Researcher in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Flexible work hours, open office environment so you can talk to colleagues easily, and its fairly collaborative within research groups.
cons: You pay into health insurance but you do not get it. You pay into the graduate student union but you are not represented by them for all of them. You do not get tuition remission. Do not work as Staff level 3 at Rutgers.

review_title: Excellent educational opportunities with the bureaucracy of a state institution
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Extremely bright, creative professors and clinicians. Great opportunity for training and learning. Givt type schedule for days off
cons: Bureaucratic way of doing things. Tenured profs set in their ways unmotivated to improve working conditions. Many are happy w status quo and speak about improvement but dont want to push to do it. Change is slow and met with resistance.

job_title: Research Associate in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The people there is very helpful and efficient. A very good place to live, close to New York city and PA.
cons:
The news about the university are not clearly shown on their website.
The administative offices are distributed in different campus.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great benefits. You work with accomplished faculty, who are also kind people. New Brunswick also offers a lot of things to do at night and on weekends. Also, it is so close to New York.
cons: It is a large, complicated institution. Simple requests can be very difficult. There is also a lot of work to be done and not enough employees to do it.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Learning curve, benefits as a student faculty and many opportunities out there for you to explore. Proximity of buildings in the campus.
cons: Bad location especially the downtown is dangerous at night. Need more protection from the campus however the transport system is awesome.

review_title: Relaxed place to work but not much opportunity to grow
job_title: Research Associate in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Nice campus
Relaxed atmosphere
People seemed happy to come to work everyday
Salary is competitive compared to other universities including NYC
cons:
Too relaxed, people in administration are too bureaucratic
Paperwork takes forever
A lot of wasted empty space
Isolated from other research hubs

job_title: Student Worker in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Professional staff and all the associate directors take their time to coach and mentor their students. lots of opportunity for growth and learning new things. makes college more than just class, rather a learning experience. Most of what I "got out" of college was from the Dept of Student Life
cons: None that are notable to comment on!

review_title: Has potential to be great but falls short
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Opportunities  to meet new people and join clubs
cons: Most opportunities are difficult to find and involve much personal effort just to find. Class focuses much on theory and just briefly give you the chance to do lab work. Large classes give intimidating experience and a general disconnect from the professor.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great benefits & budget resources to accomplish work, national profile leads to excellent career opportunities in higher education.
cons: Inconsistent pay scales across employees with similar education/experience, leadership doesn't support work and life balance, staff numbers and support inconsistent across division

job_title: Admissions Representative in Newark, NJ
pros: None. Do not waste your time and energy applying here or working here. I left, and it was the best decision I ever made.
cons: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook. Best advice is to stay quiet, or hide in your office/cubicle. No one cares, as long as you do nothing and pose no challenge to management you will have a job.

job_title: Undergraduate Student Researcher in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Got real world lab experience and a taste of how a full time job would be since I work 30 to 35 hours a week.
cons: Very stressful experience. Unrealistic expectations from my lab supervisor. Gave me a project that I had no experience with and expected me to be able to complete it in 3 months. I only got 3 credits for the work. Came in on 2 week ends and even the 4th of July.

job_title: in Piscataway, NJ
pros: flexible hours and you can come in whenever you want you would might even get the key to the lab of you are a full time employee
cons: Lonely and autonomous work. If you need help you prof. might be in her office but the only way to get help in the lab is by asking your pi's

job_title: Assistant Coordinator in Newark, NJ
pros: Great place to work. Everyone helps each other out. Not much room to grow. Its possible to grow but not as you want would probably want to.
cons: Not many cons. I like to work here and I still want to work here. Its hard to get a position here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Benefits are great (paid time off and health care), stability, tuition remission (although tuition remission counts as your salary so you are taxed heavily), aren't expected to work 60 hour weeks
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy, things move very slow, little room to advance, tuition remission counts as your salary so you are taxed heavily, a lot of politics

job_title: Desk IT Consultant in Newark, NJ
pros: Really good experience to work on campus at the start of your career and get good exposure to the working style in the IT department and enhance your communication skills by coomunicating and consulting different clients
cons: Time management becomes little difficult with the concentration and primary focus on studies which should not change and is kind of difficult if you are a average student

review_title: Work-Study at Rutgers Student Activities Business Office
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: It provides me with real life applications of what I'm learning in school. It's a small office which is nice because you get to know your colleagues.
cons: You can only work a certain amount of hours bc there are so many students that have to work along with you and they have to fit into the schedule somewhere.

job_title: Computer Science Learning Tutor in Rutgers, NJ
pros: A large number of students with excellent diversity made my current job challenging but beneficial. Beneficial in terms of get along with all kinds of people, sharing good ideas and learning to develop robust design decisions.
cons: Good amount of education resources but not always allocated evenly. Lack of efficient responses for meet the need of such a great amount of students.

review_title: Nice place to work but it is a bureaucracy
job_title: Instructional Designer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great benefits, flex time,  access to things like gyms and university activities of free or at a low price.
cons: Silos, every department does things there own way, performance appraisals not given on a regular basis, no salary increases on a regular basis either.

review_title: Enjoyed my time with the lab
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Rutgers has a pretty solid biomedical sciences program. Your experience will vary tremendously based on who your PI is.
There is good postdoc support: postdoc appreciation day, iJobs program
cons:
Departments could give PIs better financial support.
Sometimes there is annoying red tape with travel reimbursement, animal facilities, etc.
I would have stayed if a position would have been available after my postdoc.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
-There are usually open positions every semester for graduate teaching assistants and/or interns
-Opportunities are sent via email, easy to reach out and pursue
-Must attend lectures, take notes, grading, and hold office hours
cons: -Payment set up can be confusing at times, but the rate is pretty good for the time needed to put in for the position

review_title: Although experiences vary by department and school, pay is probably consistently underwhelming across the University.
job_title: Aresty Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: It's a good way to start adding to your résumé in college and get to know better the professors and their work.
cons: Depending on your situation, there may be little to no guidance in your first research venture. There's also no such thing as overtime, just working to get anything accomplished.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The position allows me to have experience with different HR Generalists and learn key factors of the job; Develop professional data entry skills; Develop communication skills; and more
cons: Even though the overall experience is great, however, it is rare to be part of an official project or assignment.

job_title: in Newark, NJ
pros: Benefits and people are very nice.  Good place for advancement.  If you are part of the union Raises are  not the best. Other companies offer better raises
cons: The location is not very safe if you are based out of Newark. I would advise not going out for lunch. Not safe .

job_title: Office Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Very understanding supervisors, if I needed time off for schoolwork, it was almost always given to me.
Pay raised up in my last year, $11/hour was decent as a student
Basic clerical work was fairly easy to do.
cons: Working with students can either be great or completely terrible.

job_title: PR Specialist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: It varies department to department, but overall my experience has been that the work is slow, steady, and stable. Very low stress.
cons:
Slow pace!!!

Not a lot of room for advancement within some departments. You might need to switch around the university to get higher pay. 

Some departments pay significantly more than others. Pay is dependent on the department.

review_title: A lot of great experience, but the company is behind in technology and innovation
job_title: Prepress Intern in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Respect for employees, flexibility, allow interns to have real work experience, small staff that works well together
cons: Lack of funding makes the Press behind in technology and reluctant to take on new big projects

job_title: in Newark, NJ
pros:
- collegues helpful
-decent benefits
-hours were good
-no travel for work 
-great career move in terms of other opportunites after
cons: -pay was low to live on in NJ, didn't get good bonuses either, about 3% if you are lucky or very sucessful.

job_title: Help Desk Supervisor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Work around your class schedule, great working environment/people to work with, easy to find coverage when you need to take off, very understanding management.
cons: Don't take this job unless you have a lot of patience and like to help people, there are lots of calls that you have to handle with technologically handicap folks.

job_title: Student Worker in Piscataway, NJ
pros: I am a student and just graduated from Rutgers University. I did work study program in Rutgers for one year. I work in Statistic department and everyone there were very nice. All of them are friendly to our student worker.
cons: I only did work study program there as a part time job. I don't fell too much Cons. Thank you.

job_title: Geoscience Scholar Program Teaching Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: Great internship in the summer to have since it only lasts about a month. Great pay for the amount of work you have to do. Good experience if you plan to teach in the future or for reinforcing simple geologic concepts.
cons: No real cons, really enjoyed working with Rutgers University and the Department of Earth and Environmental Science.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Mantua, NJ
pros: Work life balance is easy to obtain.  Friendly staff and good collaborative enviroment
cons: Lack of control on what is taught and how it is graded.  Lack of knowledge of how to best prepare students for the test.

job_title: Principal Secretary in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Rutgers has excellent benefits including tuition remission and a pension.
cons: I find it difficult to advance within the University if you are working in a small office.  A lot of the open positions are filled within their department.  I received my masters degree from Rutgers over three years ago and haven't been able to move up.

job_title: OIT Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
- flexible hours
- amazing coworkers and supervisors
- convenient location: you can request shifts in  labs close to your classes for minimal travel time
cons:
- (at least for this particular year) overstaffed, so many consultants didn't get as hours as they wanted
- stuck with assigned shifts once the permanent schedule comes into effect

review_title: Federal Work Study Position - Below Average Experience
job_title: Student Consultant in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Minimal work
Flexible Hours
Could do whatever you want on your laptop (watch movie, play game, homework) when free
cons:
Not challenging
Zero chance of raise
Won't allow more than 20 hours without giving you hard time
Depends on the boss but the ECS department has annoying management

job_title: Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Good benefits and a lot of room for advancement
cons: It is big organization, so be ready for bureaucracy

job_title: Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Flexible, great people, benefits, activities, courses
cons: lack of control, bullying by management,

review_title: Very positive... great environment for higher learning
job_title: Athletics in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Very positive... great environment for higher learning. Close to New York City, Philly, mountains and the shore.
cons: It's a state university so there's total transparency.... You need to be ready for expendatures to be on the front page of the newspaper

job_title: Postdoctoral Associate in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Access to industrial partners was easy. Close availability of other departments, multiple facilities accessible for work.
cons: Not very collaborative, a lot of conflict amongst faculty.  Some equipment is not in very good state, lack of funding has left some labs abandoned in dust filled states.

job_title: Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: People are friendly and great to work with. They keep you updated with paid trainings and meetings.
cons: When hiring full-time staff, they tend to be biased in their decisions as I know of a couple full time staff members who should not have been recently hired

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I was a teaching assistant and graduate assistant for 5 years at Rutgers and it is a reasonable place to work if you like research.
cons: It's a public university so  funding became difficult after the financial crisis. It is difficult to try and do blue sky research when you are uncertain every semester whether you'll be funded or not.

review_title: A University with many opportunities to offer
job_title: Aspiring Analyst (Energy/Utilities Field) in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: OIT treats student-workers with respect and understanding. Management is very empathetic and concerned about the well being of its employees. Great training opportunities, and job can be a worthwhile challenge if you apply yourself
cons: Somewhat limited ability to make structural changes.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
-Great network of people, especially during job search towards the end of 2nd year
-Get paid extra for teaching courses at the pharmacy school (other programs mandate teaching)
cons: -Very low pay and lack of transparency on how the partner company's money is being spent. (i.e. partner company pays Rutgers ~82K per fellow per year and Rutgers only pays its fellows $46,500 annually)

review_title: Good for starting out. Not much else
job_title: Student Worker in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
$11 an hour. But the minimum wage in NJ is $10 so...
Hours are flexible. Minimum 8 hours a week
Co workers are nice
cons:
You smell like the dining hall when you leave
Not consistent
Management could be better
Some workers are treated much better than others.

review_title: Life as an Orientation leader at Rutgers New-Brunswick
job_title: Orientation Leader in Piscataway, NJ
pros: You learn a lot from this position. Makes you extremely comfortable with the school. Helps you became better at public speaking. Improves your confidence. Helps you become a great leader.
cons: This isn't necessarily a bad thing but it takes up most of your summer.

review_title: Rutgers University is a great academic university too often overlooked by New Jersey residents.
job_title: Administrator in Newark, NJ
pros: Great benefits, lots of vacation and sick time, and free tuition for children.
cons: Structure of the school still confuses most students. Nobody understands the Rutgers system of campuses and schools.

review_title: Great place but expensive to some extend
job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: NJ is the garden state, a lot of trees and parks. Many restaurants from different cuisines. Good service facility. Close to New York and many other big cities.
cons: Road condition is poor. Housing is expensive AND houses are old. Service is of course expensive too. But overall, your income lets you afford the expenses.

review_title: Good people, flexible, but can get boring
job_title: Dining Services Worker in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: People you work with are great, and managers are very flexible and willing to work with your schedule
cons: When there are shortages, it can be very stressful for people that are working busy shifts as they need more hands to run efficiently.

review_title: Good work environment, lots of jobs available, but at times unorganized
job_title: Program Coordinator in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Tuition reimbursement, outstanding benefits, fresh and innovative environment
cons: Lots of people acting like they're working, not much guidance, sometimes is too large of a workplace.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Newark, NJ
pros: From my point of view as someone new to the East Coast, it pays quite well. Work hours are flexible, and my immediate supervisor is incredibly supportive
cons: Things are really messy with the merger between Rutgers and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. It feels like no one knows exactly what is going on.

job_title: Systems Administrator in Newark, NJ
pros: flexible work schedule, benefits, good heath care
cons: endless bureaucracy and lifers (ppl who do nothing but collect a paycheck).  Lot of drama from coworkers to those in central administration, high expectations but no funding to perform tasks needed.  High turnover and too much politics

job_title: Help Desk Consultant in Newark, NJ
pros: It’s a great family atmosphere. It is a great opportunity to learn and grow. The staff (part time and full time) are very friendly. The department has a lot of structure and the work experience is very valuable
cons: I can’t really think of any!

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The TA/Grad Assistant Union at Rutgers is awesome! Complain about the low pay all you want, you can't beat the tuition remission and health benefits. They are PAYING you to better yourself and the work they ask for in return is minimal. Awesome.
cons: Some may complain about the low pay.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Large number of facilities with well respected investigators in the field.  All the equipment needed to do whatever research you are interested in.
cons: Not much help in graduating in a specific amount of time or finding a job.

job_title: Graduate Student in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: as an international student, studying in rutgers is an awesome experience that happens in my life. doing research in this environment is a great pleasure
cons: sometime the professor is too rush to teaching. they kind of want to told you everything they know but you will have a hard time mastering them.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Very interdisciplinary, a  lot of opportunities for collaboration, good industry ties, open floor plan in labs, part of NIH BEST program
cons: Administrative issues can arise a lot, program is relatively young so frequently changing requirements, funding is usually tight

job_title: Postdoctoral in Piscataway, NJ
pros: well organised setup and facilities., good place to start off for career development in research. Though the salary is less, the benefits are good, as you will be considered as state employee.
cons: Considering that it is postdoc job, the salary paid is just to survive and is living in New jersey with Postdoc salary is very frustrating financially.

review_title: Bureaucratic State University with Great Benefits
job_title: Program Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Great benefits and absence and vacation day policies, gives employees a large number of holidays
cons: Being a state school, there is a lot of bureaucratic red tape when trying to get anything done.

job_title: Customer Service in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Some friendly people that actually like to work 
Current changes in management 
New system changes
cons:
A lot of older full time employees that do the bare minimum 
Everyone is focused on their title and not their work 
Everything takes forever to get done 
Terrible financial system

job_title: Alumni Relations Officer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Better money than any other campus job.  Atmosphere with peers is a good one.  Days go by fast.
cons: Sky high turnover rate, and they want to keep it that way.  More ways to get rid of you than keep you.

job_title: Student LIbrarian in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
The work is not too difficult, slow movement. 
All work is manageable, very easy.     
Great benefits and good hours (adjustable).
cons:
Must deal with students, faculty, and staff. 
The pay is low, minimum wage. 
The workload gets busy during the beginning and end of the semester.

review_title: One of the best public research institutions in the country
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: I think the best thing about Rutgers are the large amount of resources available and the diversity of its faculty and student base.
cons: On the same token, you have be willing to navigate the system to get what you need done. Also, sometimes the bureaucracy can be overwhelming.

job_title: Research Associate in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Job at Rutgers has immense educational opportunity. Employer gives lot of flexibility to maintain work life balance. Benefits are industry standard with added benefits like free tuition for employee and children.
cons: Salary at Rutgers is low compared to industry. Some departments are not structured well so career paths are not very clear.

review_title: Enjoyable job with very friendly coworkers and supervisors
job_title: Computing Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: There are many areas for advancement and multiple opportunities to get raises. You can choose your own hours and if you have a conflict, the supervisors work with you to resolve it.
cons: Work shifts often conflict with class schedule so its hard to find shifts that dont conflict with class.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Camden, NJ
pros:
Tuition Remission
Generous paid time off
State employee benefits
Pension plan
Employee discounts
Too many to list
cons:
Employee pays for parking and it's difficult to find a spot
Union dues
Too much red tape

job_title: Ph D Candidate in Piscataway, NJ
pros:
Gives many career opportunities. 
Its a nice big university. 
Has good professors.
It is close to New York City
cons: The social life around is not that great. This university is in a small almost dead city. You are going to love this city for 1 months but after that you are going to hate this place.

job_title: Production Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: You will become an expert in everything your job position entails. Meet a lot of good hearted people.
cons: There may not be a lot of people who do the same work as you, similarly, most of the people around you are doing very specific things. Also, half the University never responds to their e-mail.

review_title: Diversity abounds in students and employees.  A great learning tool.
job_title: Business Aide in Newark, NJ
pros: Great opportunities to learn about other departmental duties and meeting staff members.  Studies available for advancement possibilities and personal growth.
cons: Raises aren't plentiful due to budgets in constant disarray.

review_title: It depends on who you work for
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: the benefits were great as were the co-workers and the research work was very interesting.
cons: Depending on who the boss/supervisor is it can be a living hell and medical school faculty tends to be merciless.

job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in Monroe Township, NJ
pros: Great student jobs at the computer labs around all campuses. Good pay, flexible schedules.
cons: Scheduling issues, sometimes there were not enough shifts to go around and you would end up with few hours or not the best shift times.

review_title: One of the best research universities
job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The research PIs are absolutely knowledable, helpful, friendly and understanding at Rutgers Biomedical Engineering Department.
cons: not much university-wide recognition for research done by undergraduates

review_title: Great place to work at, especially for students.
job_title: Information Technology Consultant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Very accommodating work schedule. 3 hour blocks and catered to student class schedule. Overall very relaxed environment and homework can be done in downtime.
cons: Shifts are awarded on a lottery basis and sometimes you may not get the shifts you wanted. That is really the only downside.

job_title: Specialist in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Great job for students to work on campus. Great learning experience for sales, flexible hours, responsible management. Very engaged on campus life and
cons: Pay could be a bit higher and there could be restrictions lifted on the Specialists to better help customer needs and demands.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Newark, NJ
pros: Very good program. I worked in the lab of Dr. Mona Batish and she is a very supportive PI. Helped me mold my thesis project and become an independent researcher while exploring career options outside of academia.
cons: Administration can be very messy. Keep a copy of everything! They are bound to lose it.

job_title: Fitness Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: The work at Werblin Recreation Center as a fitness assistant is an easy job for making some money while still in school.
cons: The pay is similar to working anywhere else, it pays about minimum wage. Also if you are newer you have to work the crappier hours like Friday morning or the weekend.

review_title: I have had a extremely positive experience
job_title: Designer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I have a great work environment in the office that I work in.  You feel comfortable and have job security.
cons: When working for a big university there are limitations.  I have to work with a certain design set and I cannot stray from the pre-set paramaters.

job_title: Laboratory Support Specialist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The compensation is outstanding.  Benefits are great.  Vacation/sick time is on par with other academic institutions.  Family/work balance is very good.  Can be very flexible, depending on your position and department
cons: It's a big bureaucracy.  Can be difficult to get things done.

review_title: Good place for current student to work.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: Good for current student who want to have a bonus income in campus. Very convenient for transportation. The best of the job is to enhance your interpersonal skills.
cons: Need to face challenge from students in class. Need to be very well prepared in everything taught in class.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Highland Park, NJ
pros: Certain departments / research groups are top of their field; low pressure environment; above-average dining facilities
cons: Low concentration of top-performers; you'll need to filter through people to find the ones who are truly exceptional to surround yourself with those you seek to emulate and learn from.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: As part of RPIF, you spend 90% of your time at the company and 10% at Rutgers for various functions like PDD, teaching. etc. Great way to get into pharma industry.
cons: The pay is definitely not what a pharmacist coming out of college typically looks for, but good opportunity for growth.

review_title: Easy work once you get the hang of it, but terrible hours and pay (biweekly stipend - not worth it).
job_title: Residence Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: - As a student worker, your housing is paid for at Rutgers University if you wish to live on campus.
cons: - Terrible management, a lot of politics.

review_title: I have gained a lot of experience at Rutgers.
job_title: Patient Scheduler in Newark, NJ
pros: The hours and benefits are great. Able to retire after 25 years of service with health insurance and full pension.
cons: Campus was in Newark which is a bad community. Minimal raises and you have to pay for parking.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Decent salaries with some room for advancement. Do provide opportunities for entry level positions with a good chance of advancement within the department.
cons: Management could listen and use employee input more to effectively improve the work environment and make operations function smoother. There is a laps in communication between management and lower level employees.

job_title: Senior Maintenance Mechanic in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: It's an incredible place to work for, especially for younger individuals.
cons: ThE ONLY hang up is the promotion process, it's BADLY flawed and requires some serious revamping

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newark, NJ
pros: Very good Research facilities with great support staff.
cons: The Medical School had an administrative change during the last year that created a lot of challenges. There appears to be a need for additional administrative staff. The support staff seemed overworked.

review_title: Worked in Intramural Sports as a referee
job_title: Intramural Referee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Flexible schedule, easy and fun job. Majored in sports management so obviously fun to work in a field i was most interested in.
cons: Non to be honest. Could have preferred an online schedule instead of doing everything over the phone though. Overall it was a good experience.

review_title: Good research institution but room for improvement
job_title: Graduate Student in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Faculty and Staff are mostly nice to work with and the campus is huge with good facilities.
cons: Quality of research not as good at some top universities but I think it will get there in the next few years. Just need to attract more private donations.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The insurance covered almost everything and it is unlimited on the expense! Even greater than Princeton U. The money just good for your basic living.
cons: The salary is frozen for 5 years. Our union is working on it. Hope it can be better for the next 5 years.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Health insurance is super nice. TAs get the same coverage as the university president.
I worked at Busch campus, which is quite safe. But places near New Brunswick at College Ave campus reports crime incidents very often.
cons: Salary has been frozen for almost 5 years. Getting reappointment is often unpredictable and stressful.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I can't say there is any...
cons: As a public university, you will get a lot of work load.  The size of classes have been increasing for the past few years, so you get more grading to do.

review_title: A university with more passion on football than science
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Teaching assistant/graduate assistant are considered as state employees, and hence get pretty good benefits such as great health insurance with low premium.
cons: The university keeps cutting budgets on teaching/graduate assistantship. More and more graduate students are losing their financial support.

review_title: Loved working in a fast paced environment
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Meet a lot of people, always new challenges everyday, fast paced, interacting with different people everyday.
cons: The University does not support it's employees very well, always waiting for other departments to get back to you which could slow down the process

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Piscataway, NJ
pros: good academic environment. The professors here truly love the work they do.
cons: Transportation. Rutgers have 4 campus. It is hard to transit from one campus to another. The space of the school bus is squeezed

job_title: Graduate Student in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Lots of services for grad students, including awareness of realities of academic job market and help getting grants.
cons: RU Screwed is real - delayed stipends, whole bunch of little problems that end up getting annoying.

job_title: Events Manager in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Steady work. University environment has much to offer employees. 
Great benefits for health care, generous vacation and sick time.  Compensation is fair, not generous.
cons: Lots of slow change. On-going re-working of the school's administrative and educational structure and process improvements.

review_title: Good Benefits but It's Poltical Here
job_title: Market Specialist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The benefits are strong and I'd recommend applying to a graduate program if you can. I've always enjoyed working with undergraduate students in my office.
cons: It's hard to move up without playing with politics.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Very good health benefits eligible to full-time teaching assistants.
cons: The stipend is just enough to cover the living expense in such an expensive area. Heavy workload if you work as TA for big classes.

job_title: in Piscataway, NJ
pros: There are a lot of talented faculties and students, and also, there are good collaborations, and very freedom to discuss your idea with other colleagues.
cons: If the Rutgers University can provide more public utilities, organize more activities, and provide more salary, it will be the best.

review_title: A complex, yet dynamic and challenging place to work that can compliment work/life balance
job_title: Assistant Director in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
-benefits incl. retirement package
-PTO (paid time off)
-the students
-diversity of the campus--the students, staff, and faculty
-location
cons:
-lack of competitive pay and merit/cost of living increase
-lack of praise and recognition
-incompetence by some leadership/upper management
-opportunity for professional growth
-employees pay for parking

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Highland Park, NJ
pros: Great benefits, when they're offered.
cons: Incredibly redundant, inefficient administrative processes for staff and students. Competitive, non-collegial culture. Fragmented system. 59% overhead taken on contracts. Nothing is easy to accomplish, here. Even easy things.

review_title: Professors do not allow admin to take training courses and HR is ok with that
job_title: Department Administrative Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: CLAC is a great resource for Latino freshmans
cons: My chair did not allow me to take a seminar entitled, "how to work well w/chair" because 'that's a personal goal, doesn't benefit the department.'

review_title: Key communications role for a major public research university.
job_title: Senior Editor in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Incredibly diverse, stimulating environment where you feel you are contributing to the greater good.
cons: Extremely political and corporate, where money and power are infinitely more important than employees/people.

job_title: Systems Administrator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Diversity, good pay, options for movement within the University. Excellent research academic institution.
cons: Organizational and leadership overall is lacking lately. Still issues of merging of medical school need to be resolved.

job_title: Peer Educator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Fun and friendly work environment. Great place for students to develop their leadership skills and become involved with the campus. Flexible work schedule.
cons: Have to take a course before becoming a peer educator.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Piscataway, NJ
pros: It is a good place for a temporal position. Very good benefits and Location is great. A lot of population and a lot of life experience.
cons: A postdoc is a postdoc. It is a temporal position. You need to think a lot about the next step.

job_title: Part-Time Lecturer in Newark, NJ
pros: Work life balance and dynamic learning environment provided and classes are a learning process in itself to being with. Enjoyed here
cons: To being with, Time consuming and fixed timing and hence will have to plan in advance during grading and recitation hours

review_title: Wholesome experience. A great place with excellent people around
job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: It has a very diverse population of students and faculty across various disciplines, thereby making interdisciplinary work possible. Close proximity to several industries
cons: Suffers from poor networking with people outside the region. Needs to have stronger connections with industries through collaborations

job_title: Laboratory Support Specialist in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: The pay, at least for researchers, is close to if not more than industry in many cases.  There is generally good flexibility, depending on department and other specifics.
cons: The size of the University leads to so much bureaucracy and inane paperwork.  Nothing seems very organized.

review_title: A Executive Chef position training the Chef's from 5 dining halls, 3 catering locations and 2 faculty dining rooms.
job_title: Chef in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: In the past Rutgers had very good benefits and a nice working enivroment.
cons: Not up to date and very reluctant to accept the food trends of the present.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: University setting is very different from corp. You get to meet and inspire young students and still feel young. All the access to free food on campus is also a plus.
cons: Status quo when it comes to promotion or raises. Not a lot of opportunities to grow.

job_title: Research Laboratory Manager in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Amazing benefits:  state health benefits, tuition remission, retirement matching, flexible hours, memberships to on campus fitness centers
cons: difficult to negotiate raises (after 10 years of working,  salary only increased by $3k); lots of salary freezes; fixed salaries- regardless of the amount of hours worked;

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: So many opportunities, fairly good salary for the position, lots of very interesting research being performed.
cons: Very demanding for time, but that's to be expected, the course work is a bit jarring, but that is likely because I'm switching fields.

job_title: in Cedar Knolls, NJ
pros: Was able to learn a lot from professors of all different background, either professor's that are heavily involved with research or professor's that are heavily involved in manufactoring
cons: Was limited in the tasks I was able to do, was not able to dive too deep in my independent research

job_title: Program Coordinator in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Tuition remission for employees and their dependent children; union positions; Rutgers is closed between Christmas and New Years so there's no need to use vacation days during that time
cons: The traffic in and around campus can be frustrating--especially during the start of each semester

job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Good position for a student. 

Relaxed environment with time to study. 

Easy to get help for problems you can't solve.
cons:
Finding good hours can be hard. Hours for the semester are set in the beginning of the semester. 

No parking available as an employee. 

Could use more job training.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Northfield, NJ
pros: As an employee, they take wonderful care of you. You have state benefits and a pension, along with tuition remission.
cons: Working for a grant funded program can be a major con. It's not necessarily the University's fault but it can make it difficult to get a raise.

job_title: Writing Center Tutor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: You improve your writing and get to help others in need. Times are flexible and the people are a pleasure to work with.
cons: After a while, the tutees start losing motivation and come less prepared for the session. As a tutor, it is difficult to teach without content.

job_title: IT Consultant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
It's a challenging job as a student. You do get to learn a lot on the job.

Good promotional opportunities.
cons: The work sometime could be overwhelming. There are lots of things to learn and training is sub-par for the most part.

review_title: Work under a professor and help his research
job_title: Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Learn new things and explore new fields.
Get to work on latest trends in market.
No need to freak out, Wonderful work culture.
cons:
No proper plan.
Lot of self motivation is required.
Getting permissions for some of the work can be time consuming.

job_title: Peer Leader in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: I really developed a lot of skills through my job on campus. It helped give me great experience, plus I think it looks good on my resume.
cons: Just some basic teaching challenges such as motivating students and teaching difficult topics to new students.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rutgers, NJ
pros: Kind people. Good team of professors and graduate and phD candidates. Helpful in learning and teaching the basics of research papers and how to conduct proper experiments.
cons: A lot of trial and error. More back and forth then expected. Difficult to complete tasks due to inefficient software.

job_title: Program Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: More laid back environment than corporate. Make sure if you want to work with students you carefully ask questions in the interview. I wish I was working with students more - instead I'm doing administrative busy work most of the time.
cons: Lots of busy work and inefficiency.

job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Good Supervisor, Value opinions of employees, salary, Infrastructure, workspace and work time flexibility.
cons: although there are not many limitations in the job, I would like to mention about the job security as hourly employees are prone to loose their job if there are any budget cuts.

review_title: Worth it in the long term
job_title: Web Designer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: great benefits including tuition remission for yourself and family members
cons: Personal experience varies on which department you end up working for. I worked for a department that worked around the clock and expected the same from me while paying well below the industry average.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Camden, NJ
pros: Great colleagues ample potential collaborators
cons: Size and complexity create rigid policies and systems difficult to navigate; A lot depends on your department.

review_title: Great place for research & decent environment to work.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Rutgers is a very friendly environment for those who seek relaxed working hours, less pressure from senior management.
cons: The campus is constantly under construction, however there is no substantial improvement in the look of the buildings or the facilities.

review_title: Exhausting and very easy to  burn yourself out on.
job_title: Student Assistant in Newark, NJ
pros: Flexible schedule to fit around days off and school hours.
cons: Amount of work to pay ratio is very skewed. Constantly expect to do more tasks each year with no increase of income.

job_title: PhD Candidate in Newark, NJ
pros: Higher pay, compared to most PhD programs; but the pay scale remains the same through all 5-6 years.
cons: Most labs don't have funding to afford students. The program absorbs too many students for its current capacity

job_title: Lecturer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
- Great work life balance
- Get TA or grader if class is big enough
cons: - Students seem to have more power than professor/lecturer and management provides little support for disputes.

review_title: This is the only job that I miss.
job_title: Work Study Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Pay, room for growth, learning opportunities, friendly superiors, resume booster.
cons: Shifts were short, location was out of the way.

job_title: NBCS Supervisor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Very flexible hours, people are friendly, opportunities for growth and annual pay raises based on continued training, they promote from within
cons: Not a lot of support from management, employees aren't listened to even when good ideas arise. Seems to be a lot of bureaucracy

job_title: Part Time Lecturer in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Work only 5 hours per week. Get paid better than most other on campus part time jobs.
cons: You have to bring your work home with you. Students email you throughout the week and it gets frustrating when you can't reply to all the emails.

job_title: Medical Tech in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Like what I do. The best save the community with good healthcare and received treatment that needed. And educationally view.
cons: Any with goal can work at Rutgers management is excellent.

job_title: Research Assistant in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Rutgers helps you build your resume so that you have the best opportunity to become employed after graduation!
cons: It is difficult to find a research job at Rutgers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Flexible and understanding of work life balance especially if you have a family. Long holiday breaks off due to closing of university. Benefits and 401K plan do not compare to other places that I have worked.
cons: Low pay. Hard to move up. Too political.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: Better pay than many other state universities for graduate teaching assistants (though previous pay increases have stopped), good health insurance, many great coworkers
cons: inefficient management of payroll, running the university as a business where the priority is not teaching, pay increases have halted

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: collaborative work environment, experienced peers, students eager to learn
cons: long hours, too much work for one person, minimal pay increases (if any), poor mid-management skills

review_title: if you have a grant funded job at Rutgers University it does have an end date
job_title: Secretary in Piscataway, NJ
pros: Rutgers has the best health benefits
cons: Some Departments do not have adequate parking and office space.

job_title: Mathematics Tutor in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
My supervisors and work study coordinators were some of the best people I have worked with.
Rewarding experience
cons: Pay is low, but can't expect high paying job from a work study program.

job_title: Student Worker in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: People in C-SOPS are really nice, and we have many different kinds of devices which are widely used in pharmaceutical industry. The skills we learned here are very practical.
cons: The only downside is that salary for master students is low, is only 10$ hourly.

job_title: Graduate Student in Piscataway, NJ
pros: good benefit, good salary for a student, high privilege for parking on campus, friendly working environment, not competitive at all
cons: few professors to choose from as an advisor in the field of inorganic or materials chemistry, sometimes have to deal with mean professors

job_title: Academic Coach in New Brunswick, NJ
pros: access to all Rutgers Facilities including food, gyms, pools, computer labs and more
cons: Multiple campuses and must utilize bus system supplied by NJ Transit or purchase parking pass with limited parking per campus

review_title: Repetitive job but good part time college job
job_title: Fitness Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
pros:
Good pay for amount of work
hours are fit to your school schedule since its a University job
discounts on nice athletic gear
cons: repetitive nature of job can make it a pain after a while

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New Brunswick, NJ
